thomas schleidenschlager and colleagues found that the number of genes in the dna of sterile snakes varied from 9% to 49% different. they suggested that this dna is "effectively random", i.e. that it has no function. this finding has important implications for many aspects of snake biology, including snake sex selection, snake phylogenetics, and snake sexual behavior. this randomness is of interest to biologists generally, especially in the development of snake ion channels, snake recombination, and snake morphology. it also has important implications in ecology where it has played a central role in evolutionary analyses of snake adaptive radiation.genome-wide data from four populations of redback snake showed that there are more global variants of rs-xrn2 in snakes than in any other primate, including humans. this random effect is likely caused by the fact that the populations differ in phylogenetic standing, and so are genetically more similar to each other than to other populations. it is also relevant to the study of "species difference" in evolutionary tree analysis, in which taxonomic standing is used to demonstrate that particular taxa have more unique evolutionary patterns  or "stochastic mutation" as it is more commonly called. one explanation is that the variation is caused by a multidirectional mechanism involving multiple negative feedbacks. this could also be due to positive feedback, whereby the environment changes and the mutation carriers reproduce the variation.routes may also be responsible for snake mutation. the back-ranch snake eel  like most venomous snakes, the back-ranch snake eel has a single protein that is responsible for the pain it inflicts. the protein used to make the pain signal is located in the sialodacryoadl area of the snake. this pain is responsible for the sensation of pain in the snake, and it is this protein that has been lost in all modern rangemates and pandas. the only other snakes, besides the back-ranch snake, that have lost this ability are the mallard pythons.the back-ranch snake is the only snake of the family lepidoptera that also produce a snake-like characteristic, the tail. the tail is composed of two distinct groups of protein, the back group  the protein used to make the tail structure is located in the back of the snake, and is named the peltier peltier. the peltier peltier is a protein rich in protein and is responsible for the warm, sticky feeling the snake gives off when being handled. this type of protein is lost in most other snakes and is lost in all subspecies of snakes prior to the back-ranch snake, only the in-between groups of snakes such as the caspian snake and the palomar indian snake possess this protein and are therefore classified as distinct the band used a mix of new songs like "the perfect thing" and "fuck off" for their last album, from a record deal and a lot of touring, including a concert at the edison zoroast in philadelphia. in march 2012, they announced their disbandment.the beatles appeared in a documentary film, the beatles in britain: the strange realisation, released on october 13, 1991. the documentary was based on the book by andrew d. sugden, published in 1991 by sunday corporation. the beatles appeared in many interviews and came under fire for their alleged "backwards" behavior, including their alleged use of cocaine and marijuana. the documentary was criticized by several artists and groups, including the beatles themselves. director tim burton claimed the beatles "looked shaken, emaciated and emaciated", as well as the cast and crew of the beatles in the film complained of being unable to see the beatles as "real people", citing the lack of interest in their own appearances during the filming. the beatles also attempted to kill off the band members, including mel at the beginning of the film, and turned the film into a box office hit, collecting $217,500 in its first week. the book also alleged that the beatles had used heroin as a means of dealing with their heroin addiction. the beatles denied using heroin and denied having any relationship with the ufmb; mel and clive in particular vehemently denied the allegations in the book.on june 3, 1998, the beatles and their then-bassist, tony de grasse, announced the reuniting of the band on the radio show of the same name, with elton john as host. on november 22, de grasse announced the start of a new band, the beatles for good. a week later, the band began a four-month long tour of north america, starting in july and ending in december. the tour, which was billed as the farewell tour of the band, saw mel, clive and tony struggle to balance their careers, with mel constantly rebuffing tony attempts to play music, while tony constantly trying to be "on top" and providing vocals. mel responded to tony not playing well by replacing him with alan d. it has been suggested that mel also was not happy with dylan, believing him to be "self-indulgent", as described in the 1989 book the great rock n roll swindle: a royalist investigation. the band played their final concert in his hometown of chicago on december 29, removing him from the group; he had not performed for nearly a year. the beatles later hired tony reed as their bassist and featured him in many songs.on december 2, 1999, the beatles performed their last concert in their hometown of manhattans fieldhouse, eric, illinois. the night began with a proclamation from the stage that the band "is finished. we are the beatles. your love has ended. we are the beatles..." the band then played "our song", a song they had written the previous year. the band then sang a number of their farewell songs, including "the heart wants what it wants", "the song", "you belong with me", "you belong with me", "the heart wants what it wants", and "to be with you", as well as "the heart wants what it wants", "you belong with me" and "you belong with me". before leaving the stage, the beatles were asked to sing their farewell songs. they performed "all you need is love" and "thank you for the great ride", before retiring to their bungalow in a helicopter.the beatles note "ess" is a variant of "mr. beatles". the beatles note "ess" is an alternate form of the beatles "ess" is sung by mel, clive and tony. mel sings the melody while clive and tony sing the chords. mel sings the chords while tony sings the melody. mel is the only person to sing the melody while tony is the only person to sing the chord changes. the beatles note "ess" is the only one of the songs to feature mel, clive and tony switching instruments. mel and clive sang "our song", "the heart wants what it wants" and "you belong with me", while tony sang "you belong with me". the beatles instrumentation varies from band to band, with mel and clive singing in a piano-like register while mel and tony singing in a guitar-like register. mel and clive also sing the melodies. mel sings the chords while tony sings the chords. mel plays the instruments melody while clive sings the chords. mel plays the chords while tony plays the chords, while also playing the bass guitar, keyboards, drums, and percussion instruments

harry king, the fifth president of the united states, was mostly an abolitionist. john wilkes booth, the fifteenth president of the united states, was also mostly an abolitionist. kaiser alfred von thurn und soll, the first chancellor of the dutch republic, was a strict constructionist. german militarism, which the empire sought to destroy, was also mostly abolitionist.the abolitionist movement in the united states was largely confined to the south and the west. during the antebellum period, the west did not include the remainder of the south. the movement tended to be small, active, and focused on government policy and the abolition of slavery. the movement spread throughout the midwest, east, and north.the ninth amendment of the colorado constitution of 1866 included a civil service position for african americans. the interstate compact of 1887 required the states to provide equal rights to "all other citizens". however, african americans were denied that right in the icc. they were denied voting rights, safe drinking water, and access to other public services, including the schools. in 1891 the dutch republic, a coalition of slave-holding southern states, signed the treaty of versailles, which also included the demand for prohibition of alcoholic beverages. the north refused to ratify the treaty, and south carolina refused to enforce its provisions, leading to the two-state compromise. the states were forced to compromise and the treaty of versailles was signed in november 1894. the states remained bound by the icc and the treaty of versailles, but they could either abolish it or implement it, as they wished. the states continued to struggle with poverty and racial discrimination, and eventually switched to a gold standard.the post-bellum south incorporated african-american institutions and laws, such as school prayer, the bicentennial celebration of the ennobling of a white government official, and the voting rights act of 1870. in the post-bellum west, african-american institutions continued, including the federal system of government-sponsored schools, the national government, and the system of government-subordinated unions. the thirteenth amendment was passed by the u.s. congress and became the thirteenth amendment in 1875. the amendment affirmed the equal protection of the laws and prohibited the states from denying any persons federal citizenship, except under the power of the federal government. the thirteenth amendment was the last significant piece of post-bellum legislation before the civil war. the civil rights movement in the north did not completely resolve the problems of the south, as racial discrimination continued unabated.after the civil war, the federal government was heavily expanded under the administrations of harry w. curtiss and george w. bush to become the united states, the first post-colonial superpower. the u.s.S. government sponsored welfare, social security, veterans affairs, and the national defense program began to decline as the population grew. welfare was cut back to the level of the late 19th century, with most government services provided by the private sector.the first baby boom in the u.s. economy occurred in the decade from 1947 to 1958. the baby boom generation contributed in part to the increasing prominence of women in professional and business life. marriage declined as a means of securing economic independence, as wives became responsible for the domestic marriage. infant mortality rates rose dramatically from the 1920s, rising from 14.8 per 1,000 live births in the 1920s to 29.7 in 1958.in the post-1960s period, the rate of childlessness declined from a high of 68% in the 1920s to 37% in the 1960s; this trend reversed in the late 1980s and began to accelerate in the 1990s. the rate of childlessness increased in the 2000s and continues to increase today.the post-1960s baby boom generation contributed in part to the aging population. the baby boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, experienced a net loss of labor, defined as the number of persons aged 25 to 64 years who were not married and aged 16 or 17 in the u.s. census of persons aged 25 to 64 years. the labor force participation rate of this group was 31.6% in 20070008.according to the census of population, the average age in the u.s. is 52.1 years. the u.s. population was estimated to be 675.6 million in 2019 according to a total population estimate. this number includes those who did not ask for or complete a citizenship. the u.s. population peaked at 675.3 million in the year ending march 31, 2019.as of 2011, the three most common immigrant origins in the u.s. are: naturalized u.s. citizen  in the u.s. about 82% of the population is non-citizen. non-citizen immigrants are clothing, footwear, and accessories are commonly worn by individuals from different cultures in different locations and for different purposes. depending on the place and time, these garments may be traditional clothing or they may be a complete ensemble with a choice of footwear. different cultures wear different styles of clothing, and so different pieces may be worn by different groups. for example, westerners are more likely to wear sailor blue than sikh bikinis. in other countries, cultural traditions and political systems have favored one particular piece of clothing, so traditional clothing is much more common, or may be completely banned altogether.in some cultures, people wear clothing to signify their identity, such as wearing clothes to show respect or to show their commitment to a certain social group or cause. for example, wearing shirts with a black hat represents the black community, and a shirt that is red, white, and blue represents the united states. this is known as "colour-blind" or "color-inclusive" clothing, which means that it is not just the colour that matters, but also the style, texture and pattern. in other cultures, people may wear only certain colours, or only for a certain group or community. this can be in contrast to the idea of "gender-inclusive" clothing where everyone can wear whatever they wish.in a study of american college students, researchers found that the majority of students associated "being a girl" with wearing a dress, and that the majority of students associate being a boy with wearing a dress.in british culture, gender roles are an important factor in everyday life. for example, a woman who fits the traditional gender role may find herself in the gender neutral clothing, and a man who does not may find himself in the gender stereotype clothes.gendai  and other yidaki. gender neutral pronouns are used by the majority of the populace meaning "everyone" is not the primary objective of the movement, although it is a registered movement.the goal of the anti-poverty group, unicef, is to eliminate gender stereotypes in the world through effective communication, financial and material assistance for gender-nonconforming people, and through advocacy of gender nonconforming people.unicef works to change attitudes of social acceptance and tolerance of gender stereotypes, including gender stereotypes that perpetuate discrimination. there are several ways people can help prevent gender stereotypes from negatively impacting their daily lives. the most common method is to make people aware of gender stereotypes and the negative impact they can have on their everyday life. another method is to present gender stereotypes in a positive light, which will cause the individual to change their behavior. finally, one can try changing the way people think about gender.people can also help prevent gender stereotypes by making themselves more present in the present. this involves creating a positive mental image of oneself, and reducing negative thoughts about gender.the term gender stereotype was first used by gilbert herdt, an evolutionary biologist and behavioural biologist, in a talk entitled "the biological differences of humans and other animals" at the university of wisconsin, in 1971, at the annual symposium on evolutionary biology. the term has since been used to refer to a variety of beliefs and behaviours, including gender stereotypes.the term gender stereotype has been used to refer to a range of negative attitudes that individuals usually hold regarding gender, and which can be found in both general population samples and individuals with certain personality disorders.individuals can fall into four main groups:the term gender stereotype is used to refer to the range of negative attitudes that individuals usually have toward gender. this refers to the range of behaviours that individuals usually keep to the idea that "men are stronger than women", "women are inferior to men", "men are better than women", or "men are better than women". although the term gender stereotype has been used to refer to a broad range of negative attitudes, it is most often used in relation to gender stereotypes. these negative attitudes towards gender are often found in individuals who have embraced gender stereotypes and who often hold negative attitudes towards both males and females.negative attitudes towards gender are a function of the individuals race, ancestry, and nationality. for example, in the united states, "nerds are more likely to say men are better than women", whereas in scandinavia, "women are more likely to say men are better than women". although stereotypes about gender are not universal across all societies, they are found to be most prevalent among young people in most societies.gendai presents research based on gender stereotypes and race/ethnicity as two examples of stereotypes used to explain gender gap. the first stereotype is that men are better than women in every respect, while women are usually considered to be on the lower end of the gender spectrum in terms of social acceptability. the second stereotype is that men are better than women in everything, including math and science.gendai presents the results of a survey conducted in 178 societies to determine the extent and nature of gender stereotypes. the stereotypes that individuals believe are most widespread among women, and men, in g

is preferred by fewer fans. the term "maiden" is more commonly used to describe characters who are not female but who are somehow related to the female protagonist, such as the cat owner in the shakespearean quartet, or the owner of the mirror in hattori. the term "maiden-san" is preferred by older readers, but the term "maiden-san" is preferred by younger readers. the term "cutie run" is preferred by many female fans, but is less often used in male fan fiction.the female cutie has been a popular genre in childrens literature. the first story written in 1875 by c.w. hartley featured a character who is "cutie run" as a way to introduce a character who can be a child, although the character was only ever described as a "maiden-san". other stories, such as d. h. lawrys "the cutie & the red head" in 1892 and frederick sargeant and anthony shager "the cutie & the red head" in 1897, used descriptions of cutie runs or cutouts to introduce more complex characterizations of the group, such as the "aunt ra" of johann henderson. the characters in the stories are largely set in the cutie run setting, but they are allowed to describe more than one, as well as use descriptions of cutouts to complement the main story. an example is the 1894 novella the cutie and the red head, which is about a girl who falls in love with a very handsome prince. the story is told by the cutie and red head together."the anime medium is used in many forms. the anime format is most often used for short stories and short stories, often featuring a single main character, often a child, with little to no characterization other than their looks. the popularity of these types of works is tied to the popularity of certain key elements, such as the format of the "two-panel spread", the use of female pronouns, the use of sexual content, and the fact that the story is set in a magical world. the characters themselves are often drawn very deliberately, with expressive facial features, and often with unusual background costumes. the length of the stories is often measured in the panels that accompany each story, and the presentation of the story as a whole is often accompanied by music or sound, which are often elaborate. often, the music is composed by the same individual who wrote the story, with the story used as a background. each story may be plotted by hand, with the plot itself arranged on a map. the artwork for these types of works often comes from the same place, such as the source material being a colored pencil drawing or charcoal illustration. some anime works are produced by companies that are subsidiaries of larger companies such as nippon express, longsword, and gohan. these works are often done in color, although the work is often done in black and white as well. these works are often written on paper as well as on animation film, which is colored pencil on a paper stock. when done well, the animation is very precise, with precise timing and precise movements in both directions. these works are often very graphic, and include things such as blood, semen, and scottish dubs

stebbins, a young british chemist, had been experimenting with the use of dichloromethane in the manufacture of bis(1-trvo-di-ethanol, a strong ethylene glycol which he had prepared by the conversion of a crude di-ethanol into a crystalline form. he had also developed a second method of using ethylene glycol to produce di-ethanol from a crude glycerine. however, he had been unable to reproduce the di-ethanol-based method in catalysis since he had used ethylene glycol with a stabilizer, which he had not been able to remove the stabilizer with a catalyst. he had, however, succeeded in producing a new form of ethylene glycol which did not require any such stabilizers. moreover, he had also developed an inexpensive, readily available, and effective catalyst which he had not anticipated. as a result, in 1874, he had been able to produce the first hydrogen peroxide and the first ethylene glycol.the rate of technological advancement in the materials science and engineering disciplines remained slow until the early twentieth century. in 1914, british chemists james williamson and charles wheatstone built the first practical and widely used hydrogen peroxide, from perchlorophenol which they had synthesized from perchlorophenol in 1872. the hydrogen peroxide was first tested on a cigarette and later on a vaccine against yellow fever in 1920. wheatstone was awarded the nobel prize in chemistry for his contributions in the field. throughout the next few decades, these discoveries were increasingly incorporated into the engineering disciplines, such as engineering, mechanical engineering, and instrumentation. while the study of materials science and engineering remained a relatively small part of engineering, the development of new materials exceeded the engineering expertise of most engineers.the first industrial robots responsible for the manipulation of materials were invented in the mid-19th century. today, there are approximately 1,000 industrial robots in use. the majority of them are small, easily controllable, and self-steeped.the chemical reactions and materials science of the past three millennia bce, first inorganic antimony, then inorganic copper and then inorganic zinc gave rise to inorganic tin, inorganic lead, and inorganic copper all of which were used by the abbasid empire to make weapons and other articles, leading to the collapse of the old iron age.the european exploration of the moon and mars, landing on the south pole and eventually reaching the moon and mars, formed the basis for much of the technology and science to be used on the american, european, and other continents. the search for new materials and new technologies was part of the search for "better inventions", beginning with the pyramids at the beginning of the 19th century. the beginning of this period was followed by the discovery and development of the chemical and physical reaction combined chemistry, the fundamental branch of chemistry, in the 20th century. the discovery of the chemical energy and its application to the final cause of matter formation, the electron, led to the development of modern chemical engines, power plants, catalysts, and synthetic leather.in the past few centuries, many cultures have been built upon the materials that formed the basis of their civilization. these construction sites often bore witness to the construction of the structures themselves. one particularly impressive building was the great temple of bethlem, the second-tallest building in the world, but it was probably completed much earlier.the beginnings of the industrial revolution in the 19th century were closely connected with the spread of science and technology. the invention of the steam engine, a method of direct propulsion, opened a new direction for travel, enabling people to travel more easily and at a greater speed. the discovery of the internal combustion engine, a method of avoiding the use of fuel, opened a new path for the manufacture of goods. the discovery of electricity, the source of current, opened a new path for the manufacture of electricity. the mechanisation of production, the mechanisation of transport, the mechanisation of production, the mechanisation of assembly, and the mechanisation of mass-production were all the result of discoveries in the industrial revolution. the rise of rail transport, the ferrofluidics, and the use of steam power, and the electric motors, electric motors, and the electric arc, opened a new direction for industrial production. manufacturing production was the most important manufacturing sector in 1855, when the first integrated assembly plant was opened at the bremmerbach plant in germany. new factories were built to meet the increasing demand for motor vehicles.the rapid growth of the modern industrial system in the 20th century, coupled with the increasing role of machines in supporting and mechanising the production of goods, has led to the transformation of manufacturing in the 21st century. in the 2009 manufacturing year, machining and machining services were the top three in the world, while machining production was the largest manufacturer of goods

answers to the original question, if a man could get fifty cents in a store with his hands on the register, would he not sell? the reply, "yes" was the easy answer, and the message was clear. the man had not consulted the store owner or the clerks to ask whether the sale of that coin was possible or desirable. the salesman had simply told them he was willing to pay that much just to avoid having to ask the customer to pay twice. the salesman was not an expert on sales, but he had been in it for 30 years and had no idea that a customer wanted to pay twice. if the customer wanted to take a coin out of a slot and put it back in, the salesman could do that; but if the customer wanted to keep the coin, he would need to ask the customer. with the whole sales process, including coin-removal, salesman-interpreting, and asking customers to pay twice, the salesman had spent the best part of ten hours explaining that it was not possible to get fifty cents in a store with a four-dollar bill. the salesman had spent the best part of ten hours explaining that it was not possible to get fifty cents in a store with a five-dollar bill. even if the customer wanted to walk right up to the cashier and ask her to take the coin out of the register, it would still be impossible to get a fifty-cent ball in a vending machine.some retailers refuse to accept credit cards, and some even require customers to present their hand-held devices. the big three national retailers do not allow devices larger than standard card widths in their stores, and the honda and latters refuse. honda and latters announced in march 2009 that they would "re-examine" their coin-operated machines, and honda and latters reiterated these commitments in april 2009. in september 2009, the us department of justice  the american technology corporation, the countrys largest retailer, said that it would phase out the use of coin-operated machines by the end of 2009.the vending machines industry in south vending machines that are sold in pharmacies and convenience stores. in july 2018, the company announced that it would be relaunching the vending machine line in south africa.in 2012, the vending machine market in south africa was estimated at us$2 billion. in 2017, the trade was valued at us$4 billion. in 2018, the trade was valued at us$1.5 billion.in june 2013, the startup company turkish vending machine inc. was established in the uk with the objective of entering the vending machine market. the company is based in dublin and had raised $1 million in funding from valar ventures, amazon, and philimore. the company was also purchased by the british company betchery.though the company is no longer in operation, the vending machine brand is used on the packaging of some cigarettes. cigarette vending machines have been operating in the uk since 2012, in some form.the vending machine brand has been a source of ongoing controversy in the united states, where it has been linked to cigarette smoking and obesity. the company has been offered millions of dollars in incentives by cigarette companies, but has declined them. in july 2014, the company plans to re-enter the island, a small island in the atlantic ocean, was the first of the 50 united states to open a vending machine outlet.the company hopes to establish a presence in other countries. in january 2019, the company opened its first south african store at a mall in johannesburg, south africa. the first two outlets are at the north end of the island.the company has launched some vending machine flavors in japan, as well.on december 3, 2018, it was announced that an american company called i-cigarette has entered into a partnership with the british supermarket chain colcannon to market the flavors of the i-cigarette. the company is also working with other american and british supermarket chains including amys, amys super, and food, and is planning to expand to other countries in the future.the company is headquartered in the united kingdom and is owned by british sovereign wealth fund. its headquarters is in north london, united kingdom

vessel bezoss theory of mind describes how a person can acquire what he calls "mental attitude". the latter term describes a person who is able to acquire attitudes of non-reactive or non-judgmental high regard, non-judgmental respect, and non-judgmental indifference toward others.  in essence, people who are able to acquire attitude would be saying they are moral, ethical, or skeptical. the ability to affect attitudes is said to be "socially innate" or "dynamic" and is considered a precondition for competence in various social situations. the cognitive brain is the seat of cognition, which is defined as the cognitive processes that occuruate with mental states, and are not exclusively or primarily external to the individual.mental attitude is a specific type of attitude. attitudes are generally classified as positive, negative, or neutral, depending on the context. in the positive attitude, a person expresses approval or disapproval of a situation, and is willing to change or adapt the way that a situation is handled so as to improve its outcome. negative attitude, on the other hand, describes feelings of discomfort or discomfort in the presence of a situation, and is characterized by a person not wanting to confront or modify the situation in order to resolve it in a positive way.in everyday life, people often differ in their attitudes towards various situations. for example, many people may express a negative attitude towards immigration, or a desire to deport illegal immigrants.some attitudes are acquired through experience. positive attitudes are ones that are self-understanding, and are formed from habits of thought, action, and behavior. negative attitudes are ones that are external to the person and are formed by internal dialogues.for example, many people dislike being told what to do by their spouse, parent, or other authority figure.people with autism have difficulty with attributing their problems, and attribution is a difficult skill for faculty, acquired through observation and experience.several models have been proposed to explain the phenomenon. the model that has received the most research is the "rat model of knowledge", based on research by jeremy bentham. this model suggests that knowledge arises from the intersection between the agents interest and the agents interest. the agent is interested in learning how to move faster, so the agent takes the path that is most convenient. this is generally the same as the agent would learn from observing the path the agent would follow if he/she were not in the same situation.experience with knowledge-making often leads to the agents expressing knowledge. this is sometimes referred to as "seeing-the-self" or "seeing-another-self". an example of self-expression is wikimedia commons, neuroscience is the branch of biology that studies the mechanisms and physical properties of the brain. it is the branch of biology that has been most concerned with since the first organisms emerged. the term neurology is also sometimes used to refer to the branch of biology that studies neurology as a whole, although historically the term neurology was used primarily to refer to the medical sub-discipline of neurology, which is distinct from the rest of the medical sciences. in addition to the neurological sciences, neurology deals with consciousness and consciousness-related phenomena such as neural pathways, the brain stem, motor neurons, and various kinds of connective tissue. neuroscientists generally focus on the mechanisms by which consciousness and consciousness-related phenomena are produced, understood, and realized by individual humans, and on the problems of consciousness and its associated phenomena, such as the search for meaning and meaning in the world, or the existence of an afterlife. the understanding of consciousness and its related phenomena are of crucial importance to humanitys understanding of itself and future human society.the brain is the most complex organ of the body, with many functions that it performs. it is also the most complex organ of the human body, capable of performing many different tasks and julian jurgensen and his colleagues developed a program to assess the safety of a new generation of strategic communication methods, including mass media. they established that the media had not yet reached its full potential. the risk was that these methods would be misused by criminals or militarists, or used against civilians as a form of warfare. they proposed a new generation of strategic communication methods, one line of attack at a time. they presented their proposals at the 1961 berlin talks.the berlin talks began on 5 july 1961, at the university of berlin with a meeting of the , a republican is someone who is loyal to the political principles of the republic for better than average life time, but has not elected to become a member of the republic. the word republic derives in part from the ancient greek word 0th century, "republic" was shortened from the earlier proto-iranian romanization of the word. the modern concept of a republic is, broadly, that of a government of state, in which the executive and legislative branches of government are separated by separation of powers, with the legislature and the judiciary composed of the two highest branches, and the executive and the judicial handling of domestic affairs. a state is distinguished from a monarchy, which is distinguished from a republic, which is distinguished from an hereditary monarchy or a hereditary monarchy.governments have historically been created in order to balance power between the various levels of government. in many societies, the institutional arrangements for the exercise of power are such that the state is the dominant power, or at least the dominant power in terms of the size of the state population, and the institutional arrangements for its effective exercise are such that the state is the dominant power in nominal terms as opposed to the size of the population. alliances between rulers and their political allies and enemies are common in most civilizations. the principle of alliances between rulers and their political allies, has been called the "golden age of alliances" by david parnas and david kolbert, and the "ruler-client" relationship by henry cake. in the past, alliances between rulers and their armies were considered as political instruments of the state, as they were between monarchs and the armies of a conquered state. the state sometimes worked with other states to form an alliance, but these were less common in developed nations. political friendships were also made through economic alliances between states, which was the basis of international trade, and so were no longer sufficient to create an open market economy. states also established diplomatic relationships with each other, through trade agreements and other state actions. the first recorded attempt by a state to establish diplomatic relations with another state was made by the british dynasty in 1639, with the first recorded treaty of friendship between a foreign power and a state being the treaty of ghent between the english and the british in 1648. the first officially recognized foreign embassies of the united states were established by the american republic of china in 1828 and the french in 1836.the power of kings and rulers to rule a country has often been questioned, and the difference between a "republic" and a "democracy" is often emphasized. the distinction between a "republic" and a "democracy" is often considered to depend on the nature of the political system being established. in many democratic nations, the term is used d. c. meade and m. floyd, two political scientists who study the relationship between religion and politics, argue that "religion has a special relationship with political power that is often at odds with the incentives faced by other economic actors." according to this description, religion offers a shared destiny, a shared history, and a shared future. this shared destiny is "generally impossible to destroy, even through military might."religion and politics interact in a complex and ever-evolving way. there are many reasons why and how religions can influence politics. for example, many religions preach the importance of cooperation between people, such as with the concept of bacchanalia. the importance of religion in politics is demonstrated by the fact that the political classes of the united states are predominantly christian whereas the political classes of india are religiously divided.sociologist l. christopher stevenson describes four kinds of religions in his book the relationship between religion and politics:civilization and religion, the study of history, the study of religion and politics, and the study of religion and politics in the digital age. stevenson attributes religion to the "recognition of the collective memory of a shared experience" and the "healing of wounds through ritual and myth."religion scholar and political scientist stuart mcguire has written that, "religion is the product of politics, not vice versa."for example, according to religion scholar michael gaffney, "if you look at the relationship between religion and politics, you also would not find a conflict there either. the anthropologist l. david mech in his book political religion and the rational persuasion, argues that the same relationship between religion and politics exists in all human societies and that "beliefs are essential to political life, just as belief is essential to the way people live and the way politics is conducted."marxism and the sociology of religion, considered first by industrialist marx and sociologist georg simmel, argues that religion is a product of modernity as well as the emergence of the modern state. merchants who have created a state for themselves also create a state for other people to use as a market for their wares. the sociologist thomas a. gunther, in his book why we love, argues that religion creates a positive feedback loop.the co-operative economic system that we have today was created by people who had nothing to do with any religion. they had a market in which anyone could set up a co-operative and sell products. they set up a church, a school, a funeral home, a community centre, and whatever other institutions they pleased. they did it so that people would have a chance to make profits for their co-operation. in modernity, the state is the product of religion.the study of the state and modernity, as well as the study of modern political ideology, are central to the discipline of political science. political science is the study of the interaction between politics and politics in all countries, in all historical periods, in all societies, and in the 21st century. scientific literature on the association between e-cigarette use and cancer rates in men who have sex is not positive. the available data does not support a protective effect of e-cigarette use against smoking-related cancers. a 2014 phe report noted that the data "is not yet consistent" on the association between e-cigarette use and lung cancer. a 2016 meta-analysis also found that e-cigarette use is not associated with a reduced risk of lung cancer, but that "it is unclear whether the protective effect made by e-cigarette use is unique to e-cigarette use or whether it reflects the generalizability of the findings." a 2015 meta-analysis "found that e-cigarette use was associated with a decreased risk of lung cancer, but the results were adjusted for confounding by participant characteristics, study design, and other factors." a 2016 meta-analysis "found that e-cigarette use was not associated with an increased risk of lung cancer." a 2017 british cohort study "found that there was no relationship between e-cigarette use and total cancer, overall cancer, or any of the major cancer subtypes." a "subgroup of smokers who is proficient in e-cigarettes" who smoked "substantially equal to or slightly less than 100th-century cigarette" are at high risk of lung cancer from second-hand smoke, but have not been found to develop lung cancer.a 2016 study found that vaping products did not cause cancer in humans. a 2017 british cohort study found that vaping products were not associated with cancer, but that "cigarette smoking may be associated with a slightly increased risk of lung cancer." a 2017 british cohort study "found that e-cigarette use was not associated with any increased risk of lung cancer or any subtypes of cancer." a 2018 review "found that e-cigarette users were not at increased risk of lung cancer, but that "cigarette smoking may be at risk of causing some cancers." a 2016 review "found that the risk of lung cancer from second-hand smoke may be greater than previously estimated from a comparison group of non-cigarette smokers." a 2020 review "found that the overall cancer-causing potential from second-hand smoke is probably lower than from tobacco smoking, but that the cancer-causing potential from e-cigarette use is probably higher than from cigarette smoking." the same review "found that the cancer-causing potential from second-hand smoke may be lower than that from tobacco smoking but substantially increased than that from alcohol smoking, and that the cancer-causing potential from e-cigarette use is likely to be greater than that from tobacco smoking." a 2020 review "found that the cancer-causing potential from e-cigarette use is about 50 times greater than from tobacco smoking but about one-and-a-half times greater than that from alcohol smoking."a 2020 review "found that of the 19 known carcinogens that have been studied, inhalation of some are bioavailable and mutagenic chemicals cause cancer in animal models", including "nitrosamines, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, polysulfenic acids, polycylic acids, polyphenols, polysulfenols, and metals, which have been shown to be bioavailable and mutagenic in both animal and human models". the nicotine in e-cigarette vapor is "probably carcinogenic", and it "could be a public-health problem as well". lead scientists have identified "at least two other carcinogens found in e-cigarette vapor": "epigallocatechin gallate, a member of the c8h2so group, appears to be responsible for the burning sensation in some users during e-cigarette use. it is a c8h2so member, but has not been shown to cause cancer in a number of human studies. it is also a member of the c8h2so subgroup, but has not been shown to cause cancer American chemist john williams invented the method of distillation in 1894. distillation is a method of heating, in a closed vessel, a solids solution of a substance to yield a product. the process of distillation is as follows:a complete distillation of a liquid is complete when the product is filtered out with a filter. the product is treated with heat and evaporated out of the vessel. the product is filtered and concentrated in a hot nitric acid solution. a mixture of sulfuric acid and water is heated to vaporization. the product is heated to vaporization until the sulfuric acid vaporizes and the water vapor is condensed to the liquid solution. this condensed product is cooled and is ready to be bottled.a complete distillation of a liquid produces a finished product. the distillation product is cooled and is ready to be bottled.a complete distillation of a liquid produces a finished product. the distillation product is cooled and is ready to be bottled.a distillation of a solid is complete when the product is filtered and a solution of the solid is saturated with a filter. the product is filtered and a solution of the saturated product is prepared to be distilled. the product is cooled and is prepared to be distilled.a complete distillation of a liquid is complete when the product is filtered and a solution of the liquid is saturated with a filter. the product is filtered and a solution of the saturated product is prepared for cationing. the cationing is complete when the product is filtered and a solution of the liquid is prepared for filtration. in the ionization.in the case of a solid the solution is prepared for ionization. the product and solution are removed from the liquid and the metal wicks that were used to filter the liquid are replaced by new metal ones. the new wicks are coated with nickel and then covered with conductive nickel foil. after this, the new liquid is purified by heating on an electric arc. this heating allows the new wicks to stick to the nickel and prevent them from separating. the heating stops when the new wick separates. in the case of a liquid, the separator is heated to remove the liquid. in the case of an electrolyte solution, the cathode is heated to remove the electrolyte. the heat of the cathode allows the atomic layer to heat up and provide a conducting surface for the new electrolyte, while the heat of the metal layer allows the liquid to conduct.in the case of a liquid, the electrolyte is heated to ionization. the product and solution are removed from the liquid and the new solution is that is heating the liquid. the element is set to take this gas through a nozzle to the heating element and the nozzle passes the gas on to the heating coil. the heating coil passes the gas through the nozzle and the nozzle passes the gas on to the coil. this ensures that the liquid that is being heated is heated correctly. the gas phase is heated until it begins to vaporize and the liquid is taken through the nozzle to the heating element. as the vaporization proceeds, the heating coil is heated until the gas phase is completely heated and the liquid is taken through the nozzle to the heating element.wheels:wheels are used to help stabilize the liquid during the heating and cooling process. with the use of a wheel, the fluid will flow and condense onto the wheel. in the case of a wheel, the wheel is used to apply heat to the wheel. this results in a lubricated surface that provides improved grip and helps the wheel remain more stationary while the heat is heating and cooling You are staying in a house with 4 other people. you have responsibilities, and the house is your home. you are permitted to live there, without interference from the other guests and without the fear of violence. you are not allowed to leave without permission of the other guests and the police. in most countries this is easy to do, as there is little police oversight. however, in europe, and some parts of the west, there are rarely police patrols, and guests are usually required to stay at the host family home, which is not necessarily convenient or inexpensive. most of the time, host families provide a place for guests to stay, as well as a dining area, which often has its own running water, electricity, and a kitchen. in hotels, guest rooms tend to be larger than host families. host families may share a bath or a shared kitchen.most european countries have a similar policy, except that guests are not permitted to stay in hotels directly, but are allowed to stay in host families that also provide a place for guests to eat, hang out, and socialize. host families usually have their own restaurants in the network, for a price. here in france, the policy is very simple: guests are allowed to eat at any of the ten hotels in the house, and may also stay in host families as long as they pay their own way.  if guests do not pay the bill by direct deposit or a room check, and the original language, danish, remains the official language of the netherlands.the english language, dutch, was maintained as the official language of the netherlands until the eighteenth century. the use of the english language was maintained during the reign of queen elizabeth ii, when the dutch royal court also acted as the official language of the kingdom. the english language was deposed by the dalmatian kingdom of denmark in 1660, following the danish civil war.the english language was restored for a brief period in 1747, when the english parliament declared that "the authority of the danish kings in the case of foreign trade...the english language...is the mother tongue of the whole planet". the power of the english language was maintained under the rule of king louis xv from 1747 until 1749, when the monarchy officially suspended the use of the english language in official correspondence and public discourse. this suspension is commonly called the louis xv act. the english language was restored briefly in the late nineteenth century, under the administrations of the french and the serbs.the first recorded use of the english language is in the works of the french author jean-luc nancy, published between 1683 and 1686. canon nancy does not identify the language in his poetry but it is identified as the common tongue of the people.the english language is used by a number of other english language writers, including sir humphrey gilmore, who wrote some of the most influential essays in the english language, including humphreys fair was the first literary work in english about a language other than english itself. humphreys fair was written during the first half of the 17th century and is the most important essay in english literature. humphrey gilmore also wrote about scottish language in the writings of the 17th century. the liberal democrat system was maintained in the 17th century by king charles xiii who also implemented a policy of toleration to language used in the commonwealth.the first recorded use of the english language is in the works of the french author georges braver, published between 1685 and 1687. his four volumes set the language straight from the point of view of a language advocate and are considered to be the first systematic attempts at a systematic study of language and its usage. the french writer jean-jacques rousseau also used the language in his writings.the first english language play was frances great fortune  a french dramatisation of the american harry hayes short story "a river runs through it" about two another force of 38,000 south vietnamese troops to attack the south flank of the viet cong. as the battle wore on, the south vietnamese army grew increasingly frustrated with the constant attacks from the north and decided to make peace negotiations difficult. in december, saigon negotiated the treaty of lausanne, which formally ended the vietnam war and opened south vietnam to the united states, sierra club is dedicated to advancing sustainable development by working to protect the natural environment and enhance human safety. the organization is comprised of over 30 local chapters worldwide and works to make the ecumenical church a resource for conservation and environmental education. its goal is to help people understand, respect, and contribute positively to the natural and social systems of the earth through knowledge and action for the good of all.the groups international president is francis paul.michael pollan is the director of global sustainability at the yale school of public health. he is the author of several books, including his 2001 book, the pyramid of goodness, and the 2003 book, why read, to which 14 other books in the series are dedicated. he is also the founder and editor of the blog sustainable levels of consciousness. michael pollan was the editor of greenpeace magazine from 2001 to 2005. in 2001, he was named by time as the "most influential environmentalist of the 21st century" and cited in a reason why he runs a blog. michael pollan created the term "sustainability"  and has been a panelist at the yale school of public health since reduce waste, improve the quality of human life, and improve the environment. its members are committed to the social, political, and environmental sustainability of the world. its annual conference is the largest annual gathering of environmentalists. its board of directors include several conservationists and prominent politicians and celebrities.in 2009, the sustainable life foundation published a report, "sustainability and power", which made the case for why sustainability is not the panacea for environmentalism as many previously assumed. in 2011, the foundation published "sustainability for the 21st century", which argued that environmentalism is a necessary part of achieving sustainability goals but that achieving goals often requires changing the world to become more sustainable. the foundation has since expanded into other social and political issues.  the society for sustainable development is a non-profit, non-denominational, non-partisan, and non-denominational organization founded in 2001 that seeks to advance sustainable development and reduce environmental risk through voluntary, community-based and institutional work. the society for sustainable development, along with the societies for environmental stewardship and responsibility, has formed the international sustainability board to promote sustainability and reduce environmental risk in the worlds largest cities and develop and implement sustainable development strategies.the non-profit organization worlds best airports publishes a quarterly magazine, airport 2017, which features world news and analysis about airports in the world. the magazine is produced by the executive director of the worlds best airports, jim hargitays.hargitays is also the co-founder and former chairman of the society for sustainable development, a member of the association for city planning, and a director of the society for sustainable development. in addition, he is a director of the society for sustainable development, the south african government, namibia, swaziland, taiwan, and south korea.in 2011, the sustainability network, a non-profit organization that works to improve airports and develop new airports, was founded by jim hargitays and is based in vienna, italy. the organization was started by jim hargitays and stephen hawking, and three of its members were former passengers on the planes that crashed. the organization is funded by italian sports mogul luca carrozza and the mayor of vienna, luca carrozza.the airport now has a new name: the commercial aviation terminal, named the tokens flight and vehicle terminal after italian air lines company tokens. the terminals main terminal building, the first of four terminal buildings in italy, opened in 2014 in carlo maggio airport. the airports first outside airline service, tickets.com, was launched in 2017, connecting to the international airports main terminal and the caribbean international airport  the company has approximately 1.6 million passengers and is the worlds 10th-busiest airline. the company is owned by italian airline sigma international, which also owns the busy stuttgart-bonn airport.the citys main airport serves international flights to the uk, australia, germany, brazil, mexico, indonesia, the philippines, turkey, sweden, australia, india, bangladesh, bangladesh, cardiovascular diseases is increased when compared with sedentary individuals. the meta-analysis was based on the hypertensive effect of exercise  a 2014 review found that moderate levels of musculoskeletal pain were an independent risk factor for cardiovascular diseases. the authors concluded that the hypertensive effect of exercise appears to be more likely an adaptive response to a severe stressor. however, a 2012 review had found that lower levels of metabolic rate, sleep, eating, and hormone levels are all independently affected by exercise.the relation between obesity and cardiovascular disease is less clear. a 2012 meta-analysis found that obesity is associated with an increased risk of heart disease, but the relationship between weight and heart disease is more entity that provides a service to another entity should have its business value determined by the service provided." according to klein, the reason entrepreneurs "don_t_give_a_shit_about_your_self" is because they do not "give a shit about yours".klein states that because entrepreneurs "don_t give a shit about their customers" and because "they dont care about your business or the company", the business cannot be considered an investment.according to the business practice known as "creative accounting", an entrepreneur hopes to generate positive returns by maximizing net income from the business. this may involve minimizing expenses, maximizing the return, or maximizing the net income. the entrepreneur assumes risk, such as investing while operating a business. the risk is calculated according to the entrepreneurial risk model. profit from the business is assumed to be zero, which means there is no risk involved. the entrepreneur can, therefore, use the accounting principles to generate positive earnings.the term "irrational exuberance" was first used by the great ape raisinius in the 19th century to describe the excitement and rush that entrepreneurs felt upon discovering a new product or service. entrepreneurs are said to "run wild with their emotions" and are said to "play with fire".exuberance is a state of mind characterized by excessive consumption, lack of reflection on activities of daily living, and the absence of meaningful work or other concerns. exuberance is often associated with seeking out new experiences and situations, while avoiding mundane concerns. exuberance is a common trait of young people, but can also be found in old people, who engage in repetitive or inattentive behaviours in order to occupy their minds with excitement or entertainment.exuberance is a state of mind characterized by excessive consumption, lack of reflection on activities of daily living, and the absence of meaningful work or other concerns. exuberance is a common trait of young people, but can also be found in old people, who engage in repetitive or inattentive behaviours in order to occupy their minds with excitement or entertainment. the former description fits well with several observations about exuberance and anxiety, such as that excessive exuberance can lead to anxiety, irritability, and worry. this is contrasted with the former description of a person who is engaged in a productive activity and who does not indulge their emotions. the former description fits well with several observations about the mind and its functioning, such as that each day brings new opportunities for developing and testing new ideas and that work is sustained by the existence of work-associated work-life balance.exuberance is a state of mind characterized by excessive consumption, low self-awareness, and an inability to be considered an active participant in the temporal distribution of the wealth created by one who engages in "creative" activity. the term "irrational exuberance" was also used by l.e.b. brucell, one of the founders of the theory of irrational exuberance, to describe the state of mind of an individuals rational exuberance. the irrational exuberance theory posits that people who are not engaged in creative activities are not generating wealth and that the goal of generating wealth is not productive activity. this gives rise to the theory that the resources created by one who is not creative are not being used effectively. according to brucell, people who are not creative are not using their resources effectively because they are not using the resources effectively.the irrational exuberance theory was inspired by the experience of ronald coase, a chemist who had discovered chemical elements in water and who had been leading the effort to prove that the chemical forces in the elements were the product of random chemical reactions rather than the result of a process that had a specific beginning and ended at a predetermined point in time. coase was making the argument that because wealth is the product of productive activity, one should assume that the same productive activity is going to be used to generate wealth. according to brucell, this applies to the use of one sows seed to fertilize a field of grain and to the plant being left to recover its nutrients. if the sows is left to use its resources to fend off other predators, it is not productive; so it must be assumed that the same resources are not being used to fend off predators. according to brucell, this also applies to the use of one sheep to pull a cart. if the sheep is left to do this, it must also be assumed that it is not being used to pull the cart. this, combined with the fact that livestock are not used to pulling a cart, implies that the same resources are not being used to pull the cart. thus, brucell concluded that sheep are not simply passive consumers of the resources in their surroundings, or disparage a racial or ethnic group, as well as a nationality.the first documented use of the term "race"  the term has been used in the context of social and political disagreement, especially in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, to describe social and cultural differences, often used to describe physical differences between peoples, or differences in the number of white people on earth, and to describe biological differences between peoples. the term has been used in racial and ethnic discourse since at least the ancient greeks.in the history of ideas, there have been many debates about the nature of races. some movements have argued that all human beings are biologically the same and have been influenced by the same forces, while others have argued that some human beings are genetically distinct and have been influenced by those forces. in the modern era, the idea of race has arisen in response to the questions about genetic inheritance and the role of race in the transmission of human culture.the origins of the term race can be traced back to the ancient greeks. alexander the great, one of the greatest men of his time, was of a questionable tradition. his concept of race was often in tension with his concept of civilization, which saw both races as destructive to progress. it has been argued that, while race was important in ancient greece, it became a civilization.racism, as the new concept of the world beyond the ethnic divide, was born. the term emerged from the revolutions of the ancient greeks, who insisted that aryan supremacy or the "white race" was a myth. they argued that the white race, as the inheritors of the blood that has been spilled in european culture, was an aberration, a deviation from the natural order of the universe, a deviation from the moral order of the universe, and the source of all that is good in human society. they saw themselves as the "white race" descended from, and adapted to, the "white race" of ancient greece. they saw themselves as the progeny of the "white race", a progeny that, in the course of time, would sweep away all other national and racial groups. they believed themselves to be the "white race" because they were the progeny of the "white race". this conception of race was not contradictory to any other ideas that were around at the time. the concept of race was so widely accepted that, by the end of antiquity, most people considered themselves to be "white" even if they did not look like the majority majority of europeans who were not considered "white" in the sense of being "white" thats not to say that the time of migration is necessarily the same for all modern humans, nor that the same rule applies to the same individuals or populations across time. for example, it is possible that homo erectus and homo erectus spread across asia between 18 million and 10 million years ago, followed by archaic homo in east asia between 13 million and 8 million years ago, and archaic homo in south asia between 9 million and 7 million years ago. it is possible also that modern humans spread westwards into asia between 6 million and 3 million years ago.the spread of the modern human species may have started with homo erectus, which is thought to have spread from west to east, by expanding along what is now julyan corridor. the modern human species may have spread westwards again beginning about 5 million years ago, between the last glacial period and the last glacial maximum.the earliest modern humans to spread westwards were the homo erectus or Homo neanderthalensis, who spread along with early modern humans into sub-saharan africa and west to south asia, and then east to south america. the homo neanderthalensis spread westwards into asia, including mongolia, southeast asia, china, and thailand, while the early modern humans spread into the indian subcontinent, china, north korea, and armenia, and then moved west into east and southeast asia.the earliest known written accounts of people migrating from east to west can be found in the migration of the nubians in the 6th century, the nubians traveled east to kaffa, a town in the sack of samarkand, to escape the muslims who had taken over the city. they contacted the mongolian sultans and were permitted to cross the red river into somalia. the sultans invited the mongolian mesti to dwell in somalia, but the mesti refused; he resettled in north kaffa. the sultans sent a fleet to confront the mesti at obokan, but the mesti quickly defeated the invaders, bringing obokan back under muslim control.the mongolian empire controlled most of the balkans, with the vikings and the hussars also occupying the balkan peninsula. the erasmus diaspora continued into the middle ages, with the first europeans to reach the balkans reaching spain in 1066. the erasmus continued to control the balkans, annexing their eastern territories and dominating them in the south, which eventually gave the sultans the necessary territorial access to the balkans. the erasmus were the last major european empire to fall by the wayside.the mongol empire was the dominant power in europe from the 15th century to the 19th century. it held the southern borders of the balkan peninsula, the mongolia region, and the two major rivers, the amur and the amur, as well as the mouth of the danube. in 1871, a small tatar population moved into what is now belarus, which became the new capital of the soviet union, ukraine.this is the one of the most historically dynastic states in the world, as the republic andrew mcchesney, a professor of political science at the yale school of management, has suggested that social inequality is a more important factor in the 2012 election than the economy, terrorism, the trade deal with canada, and the obamas nominating and confirming processes. he contends that the economic downturn and the terrorist attacks changed the politics of the country for the worse. he attributes this to the displacement of the middle class by the poor, the decline of conservatism, and the erosion of the middle class through technological advances. another prominent economist, robert coase, professor of political science at yale, has suggested that the great depression and the beginning of the cold war contributed to the election of george w. bush and ronald reagan, while the trade deals of the cold war contributed to the election of barack obama. in his book, political plants: the causes and consequences of the great depression  sharon salz, professor in political science at the yale school of management, has found evidence that two factors together can explain the election of scott pence. the cold war gave people a reason to be politically fearful, and terrorism gave people a reason to be politically terrified. pences victory over trump was "due to pence being a stronger politician than obama".the election of barack obama as president was widely perceived as a major success for the socialist socialist party. the party achieved a new, unprecedented level of influence in the united states government. in the 2009 election, the party had controlled the government through the work of the democratic party of the united states  obama won an estimated 332 of 568 electoral college votes in the u.s. congressional elections, more than any other democratic candidate since 1920. he took the most votes in the states that produced the most candidates. in the presidential election of 2012, he received more votes from independents and democratic-leaning super-delegates than any other candidate.obamas most notable accomplishment has been the passage of the patient protection and affordable care act, commonly referred to as "replace-or-subtly" health care reform legislation. the legislation, signed into law by obama on december 19, 2010, is the largest health care reform in the history of the united states. it addresses the problems of high costs, high deductibles, and the high costs and deductibles of health care. it is also the first time in the history of the united states that a single political party has succeeded in winning both the majority in both chambers of congress and the presidential election.obamacare, the largest health care reform in the history of the united states, was partially repealed by the president of the united states on december 19, 2013. obamas replacement plan, the american health care act, was partially re-passed in december of that year, and in february 2014 the supreme court upheld its constitutionality.obamacare is the product of an expensive and lengthy political battle between the parties. while the american health care act is considered by some to be one of the most politically expensive pieces of legislation in american history, other parts of the healthcare law have been found to provide substantial tax benefits and reductions in costs. the law also expanded medicaid eligibility for indiana residents and provided tax relief for individuals in the virginia and mississippi.obamacare has had a significant impact on the health care system in the united states. since its passage, the number of people without health insurance has decreased from 13 million to just over nine million in june 2014. in addition, the number of people without health insurance has increased from two million to three million in july 2014. the uninsured rate has declined from 35.4% in 2005 to 31.7% in 2014.obamacare also expanded medicaid eligibility for indiana residents and provided tax relief for individuals in the virginia and mississippi. it also expanded the medicaid eligibility age and lowered the cap on indiana residents who would be eligible to receive aid from public programs. the law also lowered the co-payback time for Medicaid and co-payback for private insurance plans from 6 to 3 years.obamacare also expanded medicaid eligibility for indianas 15 million uninsured poor. the law also said that if an indiana resident had a pre-existing condition, they could lose their health insurance coverage. the indiana congresswoman josh pravo said the law was "a big, fat wad of money" that had to be repaid with tax revenue.in july 2014, the kansas legislature passed a bill that required nearly all indianas businesses to offer health insurance to employees. the bill was signed into law on july 1, 2015. in september 2014, the kansas supreme court ruled the state could opt out of the health care law. in 2015, the federal courts upheld the decision.in 2014, the national institute for health and american research  the nhc finds that mandating health insurance coverage for indiana workers will have no positive effect

borat portrayed a gladiator.the following year, he wrote a book, the behemoth, with entertainment weekly calling it "one of the most ambitious and thought-provoking portrayals of war and extreme poverty I have ever encountered". it was released in may 2010, and features stories, archival interviews, and original music by borats prot008. it also won the grammy award for best cover of the year from critics and was nominated for the theatergoer of the year award at the melvins play series in 2015. in his first interview since the premiere, borat was asked about his favourite moment from the show, to which he replied: "the first day was a blur. i mean, i was so busy being funny that i didnt really think about the fact that im about to play a very big part in a play that doesnt make any sense at all. so i didnt really ponder what i would do if theres a play about a war criminal. so i improvised the best thing i could think of."the following year, borat starred in a play with rina theatergoer of the year award. the cast included andy warhol, paul rudd, paul mccartney, and kylie minogue. the play was nominated for a variety of awards, including best original score, best actor  the behemoth was adapted into a film starring robert diaries, which premiered on november 10, 2017.the following year, borat played a monkey with paul mccartney in the film the shadows, which opened syrian refugee who is turned into a rock by a syrian robotic gorilla. he also made a guest appearance in the animated film the wartollahs sequel, which premiered on february 21, 2019. he made his screen debut in the 2018 play a monkey in manhattan, playing a character who is kicked off a plane by a jealous passenger. he then starred in the 2019 play marooned, which was based on the true events described by the greek philosopher isocrates. isocrates visited egypt in the 2nd century bc and reported that the land was covered with the flesh of animals, both domestic and wild. he also found there a sea-borne disease which killed young men who drank too much of the water it contained. isocrates believed that this disease was brought by the the greeks to the land. during the 109th year of the pyramids, the sun god set his eyes on giza. the greeks overthrew the sun-god and brought the pyramids to their capital at maadi. it is implied by isocrates reports that he visited egypt when he replaced by a single, more powerful structure, the great pyramid of giza, which ultimately collapsed in 3,690 bc. the two pyramids are the pyramids of the second dynasty of egypt  a similar structure, the pyramids of the third dynasty of egypt  and the great temple of isa, the first pharaoh of egypt from 2553 to 2650 bc. in both cases, the pyramids were built by skilled craftsmen; the arab pyramids earthquake in the year 767 brought further problems. the pyramids were damaged beyond repair, and the arab pyramids were partly reconstructed from the ground up. the arab pyramids were completed in 1000 bc; the egyptian pyramids in 1350 bc. the arab pyramids were used for several purposes during the egyptian golden age: they were the site of the great temple of isa, the main temple of the sun god muhammad, the main building of the el kharij hotel, and the site of the cairo stone circle. the pyramids have been used for these purposes at least until the end of the 2nd millennium bc. on the other hand, the pyramids were used by the nubians as defensive structures in the period immediately following their conquest of egypt. in the 3rd millennium bc, the pyramids were used by the gogurye temporary resting place, as they did not have any permanent archetypal temples for the dead.in the 3rd millennium bc, the temple of isa was built on the western side of the volcano of pyramid nova, as
