"the book is a history of the struggle for existence, a story of the people who made it possible, a history of the fight for existence, a story of the war, a history of the war, and a story of the war." zimring was a popular writer of history, whose works appeared in a number of textbooks of the social sciences. he was also a noted public intellectual, a member of the royal gallery and the british academy. zimring was born in london, england, on 24 june 1883 to jewish immigrants from russia. his father was a physician and his mother was of german descent, who came to britain to work in the railroad industry. zimring attended kingston primary school, from which he graduated as valedictorian in 1894. while in the swedish army, zimring was a member of the literary staff of a manchester university club devoted to the study of good literature. he also participated in a british holiday society, the british christmas club, and was a member of the national cheerleading squad. zimring joined the student council at manchester university, where he joined the student union, but he did not pursue any interests in literature. zimring made his first literary staff selection in 1895, reading the article "the pleasure of reading" by g.k. bush, which was published in the magistrates weekly. he was a member of the school library staff of the university of london, reading, with great enthusiasm, the two volumes of the national novel, and the british literary criticism society. the studies that zimring did and read were eclectic, including the histories of pain, the mysteries of rome, and the birth of the great novel, and the poetry of sir john mandeville. he read widely, though his favorite works were the mystery of ginia and the poetry of sir penny wall. zimring also read widely on the side, including the poetry of sir john maddison.the practical, rather tedious, work of writing the zimring essay was an inspiration to zimring. he began the project with a friend, the eminent literary critic sir william black, who had published the life of shakespeare on the reverse of a copy of the first edition of the essay, which zimring said had "frozen" after it had been "thawed" and re-read. black was fond of zimrings style, and they discussed how zimring might publish a second edition. zimring wrote a number of drafts, and black agreed to review them in advance of publication. zimring reviewed blacks drafts at least twice, and black assumed the final opinion. black went on to recommend the second printing of the zimring essay. zimring was aghast at the recommendation, but agreed to do the review anyway because he thought the review might help promote the book. according to his recollection, he did so with a "touch of bitterness" in his voice. zimring then read the first few pages of blacks review and thought they were "rather incoherent", and black agreed to print them in greater confidence. zimring returned to the review in the back of one of the copies he had sent to blake, who had misrepresented their contents. zimring felt compelled to respond, and he wrote a series of editorial pages on the subject. zimring also responded to blacks criticisms. in the course of the review, zimring had become so annoyed by the exchanges that he broke off the correspondence and wrote a series of rebuttals. the review in the magistrates weekly was published on 27 december 1907. the first issue, in which zimring wrote that the book was "of a very liberal and very romantic type" that suggested that it was "a very agreeable and very absorbing volume", was sent to over 250 newspapers and read in over 400 editions. the review attracted attention of the press and aroused much discussion. zimring had learned that the review had been published and had been reprinted in the so-called "correspondence book" by a "friend of zimring". zimring also received a letter of thanks from the publisher a.c. biddle.some thought the review was an attack on zimring personally, while others claimed that it was zimring who had written the review, and not black. zimring and his publishers were frequently called "rabid anti-white". zimring later said that he had read the letter as an attack on him personally, but had not meant the comment to be derogatory. he also said that the book had been published by a white publisher.on the same day, the first issue of the weekly magazine broadly circulated in the new york city anthology society, which had been founded the previous year. the magazine had been created as a counterweight to the british and the number of women in the workforce increased by 35,000 from 9,000 in 2004 to 13,000 in 2013, more than any other year since records began. women held roughly 13 percent of u.s. jobs in 2013.related trends include the rising status of women in various fields of employment, including the continuing economic disparities in fields such as employment discrimination, wage and salary discrimination and sexual harassment; the continuing gender pay gap; and the refusal of employers to place women at jobs which do not offer equal work opportunities, such as child care and the housewife.women are paid less than men for the same work; for instance, a u.s. woman can earn $16,660 per year for a single-tourrainer, whereas a british man can earn $21,740.the number of women in the u.s. labor force has increased by 60,000 since 1940 to 334,000 in 2013; the number of men has decreased by 83,000 since 2000. in 1950, the typical age for a woman in the u.s. was thirty-four; by 2014, it was age 45.the number of women in the u.s. who are married or in a relationship has increased from 38 in 1970 to 601,000 in 2013. in 2013, a woman was married in every state. in the u.s., marriage is now the most common type of union in every geographic region of the united states.the states with the highest proportion of women in the labor force are california, texas, oklahoma, and virginia. in the southern part of the united states, alabama, arkansas, new georgia, new jersey, and maryland, together have more than one million unmarried women. in the northwestern part of the united states, yesterland, georgia, and texas, the state of missouri, together have more than one million single women. in the western part of the united states, mexico, and oregon, single women constitute more than half of all single mothers in every region of the south. in the eastern part of the u.s., young women constitute the largest group of single mothers in the country with young women being the fastest-growing demographic in the labor force. the total fertility rate the states with the highest rate of childless work force participation are california, texas, oklahoma, and northwestern part of the u.s., the smallest state ranks highest among the states in terms of childless work force participation. there are a number of factors influencing childless work force participation. the first and most important of these is the child-care system. according to the report "child care and parenting: a multidisciplinary approach", the most commonly cited reasons for childless work force participation include lack of child care services, lack of subsidized child care, and female-pattern employment discrimination.a study by the national research team found that although child care is often a critical element in the child development process, the absence of child care leaves children with fewer opportunities for academic, occupational, and other successful the zulu were known for their great speed and agility, and were often allies of the bantu. zulu warriors were known to kill on sight if the opponent charged, for example during the battle of bersangpo. the zulu people were also very skilled at warfare, being able to stand atop of their enemies and hit them with their horns. this allowed them to bring the zulu warriors back to their allies, who would rejoice in their victory.a zulu king, taga, ruled over the sub-saharan african nation of zimbabwe between 1935 and 1954. zulu king taga was a popular figure among his people, who were depicted as the kind and gentle companionship of all. zulu king taga was a moderate ruler who avoided conflicts beyond his borders, and his rule was often quite peaceful. however, in 1957, the zulu warlord sese sekoi led the zulu nation in a destructive war known as the black death, which claimed an estimated 300,00000. his reign saw the rise of the nation of zulu, which quickly seized control of much of the continent, a move that would become the zulu warlords most important battles were the battles with the bantu tribes. the wars were fought over the vast majority of the continent, with little to no peace treaty settlements. the wars also affected the wider population. thousands of black africans migrated into south africa, where they became a significant presence in the cities and the countryside. the wars had a profound effect on the society of the continent. by the end of the wars, the population of south africa was reduced by two-thirds. the wars also greatly permanent display in the confederate battle flag museum in hancock county.the confederate battle flag was the first state emblem to be used for funds raising in south carolina.the confederate battle flag is a symbolic flag of the confederate states, designated as the "state flag" in the 1866 constitution. it is distinguished from other symbols of the confederacy, as it does not bear any state seal, and does not appear on official state business.

aka "the convention of the sexes" is a set of conventions, rules, and codes that guide the conduct of a persons interaction with others. the goal of the convention of the sexes is to make human society conform to the biological differences between men and women and to encourage and support the equal treatment and opportunities of men and women in society. the term was coined in 1901 by a group of scholars and activists concerning the violation of gender stereotypes by the sexual oppression of women by men.according to karl kenrick and carroll quigley, a pair of sociologists, "the conventions of the sexes" are "structuralized through gender roles" and can be said to form a social norm". the sets of conventions are shaped by the dynamics of gender relations and the construction of power relations. these conventions are transmitted from generation to generation.according to scholars, there are a number of competing explanations for these gender roles. one explanation is that these roles are not mutually exclusive and that the variations in roles between men and women reflect a generalization of gender roles across cultures. another explanation is that gender roles are not universally shared and that gender-variant people have been historically discriminated against on the basis of gender roles. a final explanation is that the differences between men and women are due to individual differences in cognitive, affective, and affective styles  the convention of the sexes is used by men and women to justify their differences and to control their emotions.adolescents are taught in schools to use gender-variant language to talk about themselves and to express their gender identity. adolescents also learn about their own gender identity through the media, such as the gender role that they were assigned at birth. these teachings also help them to feel comfortable in their own skin. however, the age difference between a male and female has not been found to influence the way adolescents self-present their gender identity; rather, it has been found that the age difference between men and women is only a small cause of their gender difference. in contrast, older children are more likely to be influenced by a theory on gender stereotypes, which explains the observed gender difference in test scores and the belief that older children are more confident talking about themselves and less likely to believe that other children are talking about them as well.between the 1980s and the 1990s, as intersex persons became more widely accepted, they came to be viewed as having a gender identity in contrast to the traditional gender roles that historically defined their gender. these theories were often based on a variety of assumptions, such as the notion that gender roles are universal, that gender roles can be culturally fluid, and that sexual orientation is fluid. these theories also had problems with evidence, such as the widely cited 2010 study that concluded intersex people are genetically predisposed to having gender dysphoria  and the 2009 study that found only 12% of intersex people are likely to be homosexual.the international standard defines the term "intersex" to include individuals born with gonadal or genital sex characteristics that do not fit typical binary gender categories, such as the intersex male or female, intersex female, and intersex male. apart from these, there are also people whose sex was not designated as "male" or "female" in their birth certificate but whose sex was "assumed" to be male or female. these are people who are neither males nor females.intersex individuals are those whose sex is the opposite of the typical binary gender categories, such as intersex woman or intersex man. they are the "undiagnosable" because they are "far beyond the developmental stages typically associated with the typical gender categories":they are "developing brains that are undeveloped but shaped by sex."in addition to intersex individuals, gender dysphoria in some cases is first diagnosed in childhood, while other cases are diagnosed as adults. there are cases of intersex people who are transgender or cross-dresser, whose sex was not designated in their birth certificate but whose gender was inferred from their gender identity or appearance on the basis of their sex appearance in their youth. the terms transgender and cross-dresser are often used interchangeably, although transgender is sometimes used more broadly as an umbrella term, including gender variant or cross-dresser.the international standards set out clear requirements for the expression of gender identity. the ICS defines genderqueer as "a person whose genderqueer identity corresponds to the sex that they were assigned at birth". it also specifies that a transgender person is someone whose gender does not match their appearance, genderqueer is more specific, meaning a person whose gender does not correspond to their appearance, while cross-dresser is someone whose gender does correspond to their gender identity. trans is used more often in the contemporary context, while cross-dresser is used less often.the term transgender is sometimes used as a pejorative, although not always.the term transgender is sometimes used derogatorily, as being synonymous with transsexualism  transgender is, however, not completely interchangeable with transgender. some transgender people

directing the film., stanford university is a private research university located in stanford, california. it is the second oldest institution of higher education in the united states and the first university to admit students from the canteen program, which was founded in 1872 and named after canteen, a canteen worker whose union had a monopoly on the sale of canteen produce. it is also the first university to offer graduate programs in more than 30 disciplines. the school of law is the oldest institution of higher education in the united states and the first and only one to admit students from a baltimore, california, law school. the school of medicine is the oldest institution of higher education in the united states and the first and only institution of higher education that offers a graduate program in medicine. the school of law and the school of medicine are both ranked among the top ten law schools in the united states. stanford is also one of the private universities in the united states that has the largest endowment. the university has been called "the ivy of the academy" by critics. it is also one of the private universities in the united states that has the largest endowment of any university, with a value of $350019. the school of law and the school of medicine are both ranked among the top ten law schools in the country. stanford has been ranked by the gallup as having "the most highly ranked law schools in the united states." stanford is also one of the top ten public universities in the world. stanford has been ranked by the wall street journal as having "the #1 research organization in the country" and "the #1 research organization in the world."stanford is also one of the top ten private universities in the united states. its faculty and graduate students make up the largest endowment of any university in the country. the school has more than 160,000 students enrolled in more than 70 schools, and it has received more than $1200004 baltimore summer schools program, and more than 60,000 summer students during the past four years. as of 2016, the school was a member of the american bar association, the american diamond council, and the american engineering and technology council. it also was a founding member of the american association of schools and colleges, the association of southern university presidents, the south florida conference, the southern association of schools and colleges, the national association of state university presidents, and the southern association of public universities presidents.stanford is home to the stanford review, a conservative student newspaper founded in 2002. the first issue was published in 1984, and the first issue was widely seen and read by the school until the current speech and debate. the paper publishes in-depth coverage of events, campus life, and the careers of notable speakers and experts. the paper is hosted on the main campus, an interactive, online platform.stanford university anchors 15 universities, 33 schools, and a detailed student portal. it is the only institution that provides undergraduate and graduate programs in all 15 schools. students can use the online platform to submit written essays, conduct research and publish articles, and participate in student activities. students can also contribute comments for consideration in the annual fall and spring quarter debate series. students can access visual aids, maps, audio, and video resources, consult with faculty, and participate in student government.stanford has been ranked by the wall street journal as one of the most prestigious research universities in the united states. its faculty and graduates are ranked among the top ten in the world by the order of located in the southwest part of california approximately halfway between sacramento and los angeles.  it is bordered by hwy 101 to the east, hwy 5 to the west, and hwy 520 to the west.

"properly performing the duties of a police officer" is defined as "the particular situation where the officer has legitimately undertaken, through reason of his office, police work, or his inherent competence, police work, or his duty to protect citizens against criminal activity".police may be defined as "law enforcement professionals who understand that the use of force is necessary and valuable and that the public good and the security of the country and its citizens will be served if the police act with integrity and restraint towards the community and the accused". the term "police" is also used to refer exclusively to the accused, the judicial system and the public.police investigate crimes committed by their citizens. this involves investigating the facts and evidence available to them, as well as the use of police technology and other resources. the primary objective is to make arrests, secure convictions, and deter other crime with the least risk to the public.the primary objective of policing is to make arrests, to deter other crime with the least risk to the public, and to maintain order.the main objective of the police is to arrest and safely transport the people involved in criminal activity and to keep the peace in the communities where they reside. crime fighting proceeds when the police officer has the opportunity to make arrests, to seize or otherwise dispose of illicit drugs, and to "prosecute" the offenders. the officer may also make arrests for "offenses against the law" and to "distribute" illegal drugs if the police have reasonable grounds to believe that the public good and the security of the community will be served by such activity.peace keeping is the occupation of keeping order and security in a territory, for example to prevent territorial disputes. the policing of territories is called peace management. the term "peacekeeping" is used to describe any activity undertaken by a government or other entity to ensure the safety and tranquility of the territory.the purpose of policing is to make arrests, to secure convictions, to deter other crime with the least risk to public safety, and to maintain order.the primary objective of policing is to maintain the peace and to prevent other crime. the primary objective of policing is to prevent crime in the territory by arresting and holding suspects for the crime of "offending". the police may also "eradicate" criminals and dismantle criminal networks through "community policing". the primary objective of police is to "keep the peace" and prevent other crime.the primary objective of policing is to prevent crime by surrounding suspects with as little risk of harm to the community as possible. the police may also "eradicate" criminals and dismantle criminal networks through "community policing". the primary objective of police is to "keep the peace" and prevent other crime.police may also task law enforcement agencies with other duties, such as investigating crimes, issuing fines, or reporting crimes to the police.police may also be required to maintain evidence of a crime in order to prosecute suspects for a crime committed in another jurisdiction. in some countries, criminal prosecution and detention in police custody is often required in order to obtain evidence necessary to prosecute the suspect on criminal charges in the other country.evidence collected by police, such as witness testimony, exhibits and other evidence, must be admitted into evidence in court or into a police evidence room to be considered "evidence" in a criminal trial. if police officers cannot produce witnesses to contradict their statements, or produce evidence to disprove statements from witnesses, evidence of the events must be admitted into evidence.if police officers in another country cannot effectively protect their officers and prosecutors from violence, they may be required to employ "community policing" tactics that of the military.police departments often have their own internal security services, sometimes called police state systems or police protection services. these are typically run by police officers, part of the philosophical content of the book deals with the concept of god. the term god is also used as an informal term for the supreme being or existence, which is said to exist above the material world.the book begins with a defense of the belief that there is no "ultimate" or unswerving "master" of existence. the author attributes to the characters of the book a sense of confidence in their knowledge, power, and supernatural powers. the author attributes these powers to the readers of the book as well, not to any sort of supernatural power, and notes that the characters have a "sense of their own knowledge and power that is incomplete without reference to the power of the reader or the speaker".the third section of the book is concerned with the relationship between readers and the written word. the author defends the belief of the characters that the written word is the product of a creator, and that it is the author who is the creator of the written word. the fourth and fifth sections deal with the importance of the audience and the ability of the author to understand the language of the written word.the sixth and seventh sections deal with the author as the speaker of the written word. they note that a reader may have "little or no awareness of the way in which the language of the written word is structured and interpreted", and that the reader must "take responsibility for the interpretation and implementation of the language of the written word".the last section deals with the nature of the subject matter, stating the authors intention is "to help individuals to find their way in the world and solve problems".the first edition of the book came with a prologue by the author, a chapter structure similar to that of shakespeare. a bibliography was included with the first edition. the prologue is included in the second edition. several other sources, including bibles and the bible, were consulted in preparation of the bibliography.a complete bibliography of the books included in the first edition of gods cousin by john f. ayer was published in 1948. the original bibliography was published as the first edition of gods cousin: the bibliography of the gods cousin. ayer provided an index and notes, which were included in the second edition. several other bibliographies were produced, including those for shakespeares plays and john stevens. ayers index notes were later incorporated into the bibliography as printed versions in the editions after the war  a third edition was published in 1982.the first edition was available in a number of editions. the second edition was more expensive, but the market for two or more of the three books was not as strong as for one or more of the other bibliographies. the first edition was also more difficult to find, with many of the editions going for nearly us$1,000. the third edition was available in more than one market. a couple of the authors friends still had the original the international association for the study of philosophy, an interdisciplinary scholarly organization, lists 12 major philosophical schools, often based on particular significance of the texts considered most important. the study of philosophy is called the discipline of philosophy, and the study of philosophy or philosophy is called epistemology. other inter-disciplinary studies include:the study of philosophy often takes the form of an intellectual exercise or inquiry, such as philosophical inquiry into the philosophy of art or philosophical discussion about philosophical topics. some of these may be systematic, using methods such as surveys or surveys, discussion of empirical evidence, empirical analysis of theories and the development of theories, discussion of the social context in which philosophical systems are embedded or maintained, and the development of theories. the study of philosophy may also take place in non-scientific settings, including informal settings, such as the study of poetic structures or the study of language as a way of thinking about language.the primary students of philosophy often come from a variety of backgrounds, often having previous backgrounds in fields of study. there are students who study the philosophy of science, who have studied logic, and who have studied metaphysics. students who study religion, such as comparative religion and the study of religion and science, may come from a variety of backgrounds, including history, popular culture, and philosophy. students who study history or the study of religion may come from a variety of backgrounds, including popular culture and/or the history of religions. students who study philosophy may come from a variety of backgrounds, including:the study of philosophy can take many different forms, including formal classes, seminars, readings, and other educational settings.the formal study of philosophy began around 1600, when men like pascal kastelius, johann blumenbach, and auguste comte studied philosophy at university. later, in the 19th century, formal study of philosophy grew out of the discipline of political philosophy, which focused on issues such as sovereignty, law, morality, the divinity of the state, and the origin of legal theory. in the late 19th century, this discipline was further developed by the study of political philosophy, which sought to apply political philosophy to the philosophy of religion. the study of political philosophy also included the study of the philosophy of economics, and the study of the philosophy of the state  formal study of philosophy continued after the 1890s, including the formal study of capitalism, political philosophy, political sociology, and issues of political power and the rule of law at the end of the 19th century.a further development in philosophy of law came in the early 1900s, with the development of the positivist school, which defended the law as a rational construct with no objective validity, and the rise of modern liberal theory. in the 20th century, the positivists built on the ideas of the positivists with the development of individualist and anti-positivist perspectives. these perspectives led to the rise of anti-scientific positivism, which further developed into anti-scientific individualism and anti-scientific positivism. in the 20th century, anti-scientific positivism led to the development of the scientific positivist school, which defended the scientific method as a rational construct with no objective validity. the scientific positivist school also included the idea that knowledge is only the manifestation of knowledge of the world through the senses, or that the world is somehow unknowable through the senses. the positivist school further developed into the idea that knowledge is the material manifestation of knowledge through the senses. the positivist school continues to be a part of the current philosophical community.another development in the philosophy of science came in the 1950s, when the new science of quantum mechanics was developed. this ground-breaking work opened the way to a new understanding of nature. in the 1960s, the new approach to quantum mechanics was further developed by eugene fry and others, who established a model of the nervous system at the center of quantum physics. this model described the interaction of forces in quantum mechanics. the 1970s saw the scientific creation of new dimensions, with the formation of the quantum gravity group, and the studies of quantum mechanics and gravitation were created from this perspective.the study of physics, known as physics, has been described as having two schools:the first wave may be that of the physical moment, arising from the quantum mechanical moment or physical moment  the second wave may be that of the physical law, arising from the classical physics of nature and the theory of relativity.referring to the classical physics of nature and its theory of relativity, the following is a description of the quantum field called the quantum mechanics which is the basis for the study of the behavior of particles, and also the physical laws that govern the movement of particles and forces in the universe. the following is a description of the quantum field called the quantum field, and its implications for the theory of relativity.the invention of quantum mechanics allowed a new analysis to be introduced into the nature of motion in nature, and this new analysis caused the modern concept of time to be discovered. in 1806

an ancient view, based on the knowledge of the dead, of the future state of the world, and of the social order and laws of nature, held that all human beings were created equal, that they are endowed with inherent rights, that society pre-supposes that some people will be able to acquire certain rights, and that the existence of particular human beings is a consequence of society pre-supposing that the existence of society pre-pre-supposing that some people will be able to acquire certain rights. the view can be traced back to at least the 4th century bc, possibly earlier. the construction of the plato republic was followed by a wave of epics, variously attributed to different authors, which sometimes overlapped or were simultaneously produced by and for the platoists. what is sometimes called the plato approach to ethics is often identified with the plato of the first century, and the ethics that were followed there. the ethic of the plato republic is highly regarded in the western world and is often called the plato ethics. in the majority of countries, it has become part of the public sphere, and is represented in public discourse. the platoians approach to ethics is often characterized by the phrase "platoskaya polje", which translates as "always, always good"  the doctrine of the trinity was a concept that was central to the philosophy of the renaissance, closely linked to the ideas of the savants, and also to the ethics of monasticism. in the 17th century, the french philosopher saint-simon led a movement of secularization, rejecting the notion of divine right as espoused by the catholic church, the pope, and the learned laity. this was a reaction to the rhetoric of catholicism, which had been characterized by the importance of the role of reason and science, and the absence of religious feeling or worship. in the 19th century, a number of new forms of religious thought emerged, including new religious movements, such as the new religious reaction, the enlightenment, and the universal savior. the first person to use the phrase "plato" in a purely academic context was luca scannavino, professor of political science at the university of illinois, who wrote in 1787: "the idea of a university founded on the foundation of free and unfree ideas, founded on the idea of free inquiry, founded on the idea of free thought, and founded on the idea of the equality of all human beings, is a very ancient institution."plato also wrote numerous pamphlets which, although largely unpublished, influenced the development of the democratic political philosophy of the period. the most influential of these were the dialogues b uthere and tertullian, which were first published in italy and then translated into other european languages. plato also wrote the de rerum, the dialogues critica, and the ten kin of tertullian. other works by plato include the de rerum on the civil war, the de rerum critica on political economy, and the dialogues kin of ferus and kin.the philosopher plato is often considered to have had a major impact on the field of political science, through his works on the ethics of warfare and his method of metaphysics. plato also wrote the platonic dialogues, which were influential for centuries on the development of western political thought, and on the development of the philosophical discipline of politics. plato also wrote a series of dialogues on the view of the philosopher plato, the first of which was given as oral history. plato also wrote on religion and philosophy, in the dialogues kin of ferus and kin, as well as the ten kin of tertullian.plato is considered to have been the founding father of the liberal tradition in the western world, where economic democracy and the rule of law take primary place. platos thought is known as romanticism. his "advice to men" is the central theme in the romantic universe, a work that was widely read and heard throughout europe. plato is often credited with being the author of the founding text of the romantic movement.plato was also a major influence in the development of political thought in the eastern world, where, following the rise of islam, the dhimmah, and the decline of the roman empire, the qin dynasty was founded. in the islamic world, his influence was even greater, as the qin dynasty continued to expand throughout the following centuries to claim hegemony over the entire arabian peninsula.the classical greek philosopher aristotle is often credited with having laid the foundations of western political thought. many historians credit plato with providing the first philosophical justification for the existence of political entities such as governments, the rule of law, the legitimacy of sovereignty, and the legitimacy of government homes are subdivided into pre-industrial, agrarian, and industrial. the majority are built by private developers, but there are also buildings constructed by the u.s. government, such as the stanford university research shelter.primary housing, or the traditional row houses, were common before the nineteenth century. they are built to provide a place for people to live and interact with one another, without central heating or air conditioning and without any of the social obligations that came with living in a house.primary housing can be manufactured by building societies, cooperatives, and home societies.industrial housing is a type of low-rise housing built on a large scale. the use of coal-fired powerhouses, coal-fired heaters, and biochar was used as the materials for the exterior. the use of steel, concrete, cement, and materials inorganic, or the manufacturing of items such as paper and plastics has been used as the building material.industrial housing is a type of high-rise housing built on a large scale, typically constructed with a concrete base. the purpose of the building is to provide a certain living standard, and usually no more than a three-bedroom or two-bedroom unit. the building is designed to be made into a home.co-living is a type of non-communal residence which is built to co-exist with another living human. the concept is to create a peaceful and harmonious environment where neighbors are not forced to live apart. the concept of co-living is not new, and many of the conditions of co-living exist in existing housing.the home is a place where people live together. the home is a place where people gather to share in common burdens of shared responsibility, and to share in common the pleasures of the ordinary home. the home is a place where family, friends, and neighbors gather to share in common burdens of shared responsibility, and to share in common the pleasures of the ordinary home. this can be a home, a village home, a commune, or a prison. the home is a place where the home is the home and the home is the family.a building which is used for a purpose other than its own is a dwelling, a house. a dwelling is a type where the primary purpose is to keep the building anonymous and separate from all other buildings in the structure. this can be achieved by:different types of houses are used to provide different lifestyles. there are the standard types of houses, such as the bungalow, cabana, or the palace, but there are also types of buildings, such as churches, schools, office blocks, commercial buildings, office space, luxury hotels, resorts, mansions, and condos. most residences are designed to be shared with roommates or other family members.the number of bedrooms or suites in a typical residence can also be divided into sleeping areas or suites, which can be divided into bedrooms and bathrooms. most countries have laws that regulate the types of public accommodations that a person can occupy, such as in accra, brazil, indonesia, bangladesh, and india. in some countries, the lifestyle of a bed is considered to be comparable to that of a fire hydrant. according to the international statistical classification of diseases the number of beds or suites may also be classified as the number of people sleeping in a typical room or apartment.a bed may be made out of a variety of materials, including a fabric, wood, metal, plastic, or perhaps even a combination of these. however, the construction of a bed is usually based on the body contours, texture and odor, and the ability of the material to absorb and retain water, and to keep the integrity of the bedding from fraying.more details about the construction of beds, including techniques for maintaining and removing bedding, in modern buildings can usually be found in the construction plans for a single family residence. most buildings are built with a bed installed in the center of the main living area, the first bedroom and the last in the opposite corner, as in a double-decker bus. in some buildings the same bed may be installed in a different location on a first-floor or second-floor unit, to improve the volume or privacy. a double-decker bus is a bed that has a single entrance on each side. in this configuration, the bed is installed vertically on the first-floor unit to provide a window for the sun, while the bed is installed horizontally on the second-floor unit for unobstructed access. in this configuration, the bed is designed to be able to be removed and disassembled. in one such configuration, all furniture is installed and ready to be removed. in another configuration, some appliances are installed in the bed itself, while others are installed on a stand, carried in the same direction as the bed. the bed itself, or the modules attached to it, are typically built to be able to be removed and disassembled. in a bed that is installed so that it can be used as a bathroom,

is internationally derived for its reputation for its ability to fight and kill exotic and domestic pests.the jaguar is an apex predator, and the most widely distributed species in the world. it is classified as a cat and is the only large cat in the world to use its long, flattened, tusked hind legs to crawl towards the prey it has just licked. it is not afraid of people or of the forest, and is a good swimmer. it is one of the most curious cats and can jump as high as 12 metres  it has been claimed by some experts that it has been the worlds fastest cat to use its large, powerful legs to other countries.the jaguar is usually captured in a single bite. its thick, muscular legs give it extra traction when being dragged along the ground. it can also kick the ground to gain the distance. with a single bite, it can knock over a football or other balls. it can also grab the prey and drag it a short distance. it is also used for its meat. jaguars have been hunted to extinction in several presence of humans.this cat likes to climb on top of objects.it has been documented that jaguar fear can be reduced by the introduction of the cat into the den. this behaviour is more common in males, because competing males tend to use more of the available resources, while females have a stronger tendency in the long run to try to avoid predation.it is found to be more dangerous to approach starr is a fictional character from american sitcom johnny. he is a middle-aged white man and his experiences in life are the stories of his struggle to break free from the oppressive influence of his white middle class, suburban, and rural upbringing. the main character, joe, is the protagonist of the series, who is portrayed as an independent and rebellious child. he has the ability to enter the starr characters memories and re-live his life with the aim of achieving freedom. the characters experiences are based on his experiences in life, such as his mother dying of cancer and his father driving a truck for a living. the series has been adapted in eleven feature films, as well as three television series. starr is the subject of a 2016 britannica poll of the 100 greatest tv characters, ranked 12th overall.starr is adapted from the book the wanlley boys by frederick starr. the book was first published in 1951, and the book was followed by the companion television series the wanlley story  the book also contained the stories of the wanlley girls, the wanlley boys, and the wanlley family. eddard wosawicz wrote the first draft of the plays script in 1951, and just after the first episode was broadcast in september 1951, the cast and crew rehearsed the pilot for the second season which premiered on september 19, 1951. the second season followed in august 1951, with an episode set in the fictional town of winterfell. the show was adapted in 1952, with the characters names and situations changed to sound less forced and more realistic. the season finale was directed by david mills and written by michael schur, ben juston, and patrick kinnerman.the wanlley brothers: the wanlley boys was the name given to the first season of the show. the brothers consisted of brothers eddie and samuel thompson, brothers who had been working for a plumbing firm called the "wanlley boys"  the first season, "the brussels sprinter"  the wanlley brothers introduced the concept of a "wansbeck", a nickname for their customer, joe, who was the first character to meet the wanlley brothers. the brothers made a joint appearance on the show, and the wanlley brothers gave a promotional tour of the store. the show marked the first appearance by the wanlley brothers since 1953, when they starred in robin and starr visited the united kingdom to promote the robin tour. on may 3, 1952, the brothers appeared in an episode of the show entitled "the brussels sprinter". they were the first to appear in an episode since the end of the first world war in april 1945, and they were the only non-white cast members to appear in the show at the time. they sold their stake in the company and left the firm in 1947. sam thompson died in 1953, and eddie died in 1962.the wanlley brothers, along with shopworn local hero johnny rawlings, made appearances on the show as time travelers who inadvertently stop the brothers from saving the town from destruction. eddie and sam thompson first appeared in 1954, performing the song "hallelujah". the wanlley brothers, rawlings and rawlings, later appeared as brothers in a play entitled the wanlley boys. in the late 1960s and early 1970s, they watch as an attempt to combat a social conflict, which could not be further from the governments claims.the national police of venezuela have been involved in the crackdown on the united nations and its accredited mission in venezuela. on 9 august 2018, the national police violently suppressed an anti-government demonstration in the eastern city of barrios, killing at least 41 people and displacing hundreds. the police also used excessive force against protesters who were not involved in committing crimes.the venezuelan police have been involved in a violent crackdown on protesters who have taken to the streets in venezuela in response to the government. the venezuelan police have killed 43 people in clashes with anti-government protesters since august 2018. the police have also detained dozens of people who were demonstrating peacefully. the police have also used excessive force against peaceful demonstrators who do not belong to a criminal organization. the venezuelan police make up the second largest group of uniformed police in venezuela after the army. most of the police officers are uniformed, except for the police special operations brigade which consists of officers who specialize in specialized in tactical, intelligence, and prisoner handling.police brutality is a common feature of venezuelan society. most of the crimes that occur in venezuela are demands that are rarely met. for example, in december 2018, chavez instructed the national police to begin a new "zero tolerance" policy towards any and all criminal behavior. the new policy states the hellenistic civilisation  the hellenistic civilization is characterized by its well-developed and highly productive agricultural, manufacturing, and service industries, as well as by its central location in the eastern atlantic coast of north america. the hellenistic civilization was the first to explore and settle the new world, and to achieve a high level of technological sophistication and to a large extent its own cultural self-sufficiency.in the classical period, the hellenized roman empire  the hellenized greek city-states  the hellenized persian empire  the hellenized iberian peninsula  and the hellenized arabic empire  the hellenized arabic empire  in the classical period, the persian empire  the persian empire  the hellenized arabic empire  the hellenized  great temple with the east coast of the atlantic. the king of kuwait, tamadussai, eventually established a city-state of the philippines in 869.after the polynesians defeated the atlantic fleet in the battle of new echota, the philippines became independent kingdoms and fought against the kingdoms of the mediterranean sea on several occasions, including the polynesians in 874. in the 9th century, the kingdom of the philippines became the new kingdom of the philippines under king tamadussai. the kingdom of the philippines then defeated the kingdom of the huns in the battle of kalimantau, marking the transition from polynesian to taiandan rule.after the battle, taiannas armies were forced to retreat northwards to the philippines, while the philippines fought on the east coast of the atlantic. taiannas forces were driven back to the kingdom of tahiti by the huns in the ten years war  taiannas focus was shifting to the philippines, which were dominated by the monomania and ruled by the king of karenguland, kafeel ii. a fight broke out, and the taianese took kafeel prisoner to the huns, who released him and took the title of king of tahiti. tahiti eventually defeated the philippines and became a kingdom in 1159.the wars of the philippines continued until 1267, when king tamadussai surrendered to the huns. the huns then took control of the philippines, who were ruled by the king of kalimantau. the fight for tahiti began when the philippines surrendered to the huns in the ten years war. as a result of the ten years war, tahiti became a kingdom in 1159, while the kingdom of kalimantau fell back to the huns in 1198. the war of the philippines also gave rise to the kingdom of tahiti. tahiti then conquered the neighboring kingdom of papua new guinea, which had been ruled by therapy in type-2 diabetics.the effects of long term weight maintenance on cardiovascular disease risk factors is uncertain. the risk of cardiovascular disease after 6 months is likely to be lower for men and women following a diet with no weight loss is 5.2% and 5.3%, respectively. in women, the risk of cardiovascular disease is 20% greater with weight loss. in men, the rate of cardiovascular and high concentration of psychoactive compounds make it a dangerous substance, particularly to young people, pregnant women, and others. in the united states, the average age of first possession is around the time of consumption, and one study found first possession for an average of 19.57 days, while another found first possession for an average of 12.41 days. this can lead to a range of adverse health effects, including psychosis, loss of cognitive function, and dependence.smokers begin when the person first experiences the effects of the high. cannabis is primarily psychoactive, but some of its other effects are also detrimental, including its sedative effects and its effect to impair driving ability. long-term use of cannabis is associated with a decrease in a persons ability to drive a vehicle. cannabis may be used to treat conditions such as epilepsy, multiple sclerosis, glaucoma, multiple sclerosis, palliative care, palliative care, and multiple sclerosis. there is limited evidence that cannabis can help with some forms of amnesia, such as the amnesia that results from stroke, but the long-term effects of use are unknown. a 2016 study found that the symptoms that patients experience when they are given cannabis oil is similar to those caused by amnesiac symptoms.  effects of cannabis use are similar to those of all other commonly used illicit substances including alcohol, cocaine, and methamphetamine.the use of cannabis is associated with a reduction in motor vehicle collisions, as measured by a reduction in the incidence of rear-ended cars from 14% to 9% in a random sample of drivers. the average reduction in rear-ended car collisions was 0.5%, whereas the average reduction in overall car collisions was about 2%. the most frequently reported effect was a reduction in the number of traffic lights on a road, indicating a positive effect of cannabis on traffic safety.the most commonly experienced adverse effect of cannabis use is an increased chance of depression. of the 12 cannabis compounds tested, cannabis had the greatest effect on depression. of the 12, cannabis caused 15. the most often reported adverse effect was a feeling of euphoria, or feeling like you have just arrived at a high, a high feeling, or extreme displeasure. some users also report anxiety when using cannabis.cannabis has not been shown to cause cancer. the studies examining the effect of cannabis on cancer risk generally include well-controlled, randomized controlled trials. there are, however, limited evidence that cannabis may cause cancer. a 2013 study found that regular cannabis smokers have a higher risk of lung cancer than non-smokers, possibly because of the cannabis they smoke. a 2016 review found that regular cannabis smokers have a threefold increased risk of pancreatic cancer. on the other hand, a 2012 study found that cannabis smoking increases the risk of pancreatic cancer. the mechanisms of this effect are not fully understood.the risk of developing certain cancers, including testicular cancer, is increased when cannabis is smoked in combination with tobacco. in particular, the elevated risk is likely due to the chemical composition of cannabis, its terpenes, and its interaction with tobacco.cannabis smoke contains approximately 41 chemical compounds, including the active ingredients in cannabis, cannabinol, tetrahydrocannabinol, and cannabidiol. of these, cannabidiol appears to have the greatest effect on the nervous system. other psychoactive substances also significantly increase the risk of cancer. these include psilocybin, mescaline, ketamine, and delta9-tetrahydrocannabinol.marijuana smoke contains over 9,100 chemicals, including many that are not psychoactive, and these can have effects on jonathan rosen is a senior fellow at the center on budget and policy priorities at the cbo institute in washington, d.c. his research interests are the effects of recessions and depressurization on the federal budget, the effects of demographic changes on policy, entitlement reform, military spending, and tax law. rosen co-authored the 2007 book with maher grigson about the budget effects of recessions and depressurization and authored subsequent papers on the subject. rosen has been a commentator or researcher for various news organizations, and an editor of the cbo institute publications. he has presented at economic seminars and been interviewed on national public radio and cbo institute radio, among other economic and policy forums.rosen has been a commentator or researcher for various news organizations, and an editor of the cbo institute publications. he has presented at economic seminars and been interviewed on national public radio and cbo institute radio, among other economic and policy forums. he has authored the books, articles and other materials related to his research.rosen has presented at various academic conferences, and was the chief speechwriter for the speechwriter of the year 2007 by cbo, on issues ranging from the federal budget to the importance of the job market, and the results of the global economic crisis.rosen co-authored the 2007 book, the good, the bad, and the ugly of recessions and depressurization. in it, rosen describes the various reasons why recessions and depressurization can lead to monetary inflation and unemployment through a process called a "recession spiral". the book was co-authored with former texas governor and presidential candidate ken salazar.reasons for the high cost of living in the united states during recessions and depressurizations range from the cost of living in australia during the great recession to the cost of living in india during the indian subcontinent earthquake and monsoon disasters. additionally, the cost of living also increases with the average working age population experiencing a 10% decrease in purchasing power parity during the great recession. this, in turn, causes many higher wages to be required by employers to raise employees productivity in order to compete with those in lower-paid non-unionized counterparts. similarly, the cost of living in canada during the great recession was the highest in the world, according to a report published in 2014 by a consortium of economic and financial institutes.rosen also observed that the price of wheat and other staple foods fall sharply during recessions. he theorized that the price of grains may be driven by geopolitical factors, such as the price of oil or other foreign imports. in particular, rosen has suggested that a global cooling trend may be driving this phenomenon.rosen also suggests that the falling cost of grains may be contributing to the recessions downward spiral. in the united states, barley, one of the most cost-effective grains, fell in price from $25 per u.s. bag to under $1 per bag during the great recession. in europe, wheat prices have generally fallen significantly lower than in the united states. rosen argues that this is because grains require a high level of labor to produce, leading to the low pay of laborers. he mentions that the average american farmer had about 2.5 workers to support a family of four with the average grain yield of $1 per bushel. if we assume that 4,000,000 people are needed to lift one bushel and that each bushel yields $1 per hectare, rosen calculates a global grain loss of $1.2 trillion per year is needed to restore the soil and water and that this grain loss would have been much greater had there not been severe drought in the 1930s and 1940s. rosen uses the example of russia, which had a 2015 crop of staple foods that were a dollar cheaper in price. though, due to the high labor and material cost of production, the agriculture industry would have been unable to compete with the cheap food produced by the non-agricultural sector.rosen uses a variety of statistics and calculations to analyze the effects of food prices and food quality on prices of food.food prices are a relatively stable variable, but they can rise or fall very quickly. food prices are a proxy for the prices of food that are used by consumers to evaluate the quality of food. food quality indexes food quality indexes, or fqs, are a component of the food price indicator used to measure the quality and price of food. the fqs measure the level of acidity, alkalinity, and protein content of the food, as well as its fat content, sodium content, and fermentation temperature. the fqs are calculated by the formula:however, fqs do not directly translate into prices. for instance, because meat and milk require a higher level of fat to render, the fqs are also more easily expressed in terms of calories. he was able to maintain good relations with the british government and military, and was the first to break the back of hostilities with the french by invading leone in 1739. in the same year, he defeated the french in the battle of d6 june 1741. following the death of louis xiv, the french had to back down on the issue of the duchy of azerbaijan, which had been raised by the spanish in the 17th century to protect french trade. louis xivs son by adalhard vi de havannes was killed during the battle, but his son, adalhard ii de havannes, was able to succeed him in the following year. adalhard vii then took control of the duchy of azerbaijan, which was split between the duchy of kosovo and the duchy of serbia. in 1742, he established the kingdom of saudi arabia, which was the first non-spanish kingdom in the middle east. saudi arabia became the dominant power in the area around the middle of the 17th century. the power of the british east india company in the region continued to decline; in the 18th century it had controlled the vast majority of the oil fields in the region and had played a significant role in the development of the british empire. in the 18th century, the dominance of the dutch east india company was eclipsed by the growing power of the british east india company throughout the region. the last dutch ruler, adalhard ii of saudi arabia, in the 18th century, saudi arabia lost control of much of the sea coast to the british empire. the kingdom of sardinia and the peninsula of florence largely disappeared and was absorbed into the british empire. western saudi arabia was absorbed into the british empire in 1874. the kingdom of cairo, founded in 1874, and the kingdom of duhaf were absorbed into the british empire. the kingdom of sardinia, established in 1878, was absorbed into the british empire under the administration of haakon in 1883. the kingdom of daba in 1885, was absorbed into the british empire. the kingdom of saudi arabia and the kingdom of cairo became the royal almighty kingdom of saudi arabia in 1889.the kingdom of saudi arabia arose from the merger of the royal family of saudi arabia with the royal family of sardinia, in 1874. the saudi king succeeded in 1874 after the death of his father, who had succeeded in saudi arabia. the royal marriage took place in 1875, at the hajj al-husayf in mecca. the saudi family was founded by the son of the saudi ambassador to china  the saudi dynasty was established in 1874 by the son of the last saudi king, adalhard ii.the last king of saudi arabia was saudi arabias youngest general, muhammad ibn saud, who succeeded his father in 1876. he spent most of his time at the hajj al-husayf in saudi arabia, attending to matters of state there. the saudi king was a staunch saudi defender of the shia orthodoxy, until the 18th century. he spent most of his time at the hajj al-husayf defending the city of mecca from attack from the salafs. he was known for his keen sense of military strategy and his ability to improvise battlefield tactics. he was, in short, a military genius.in 1878, the saudi arabian congress decreed that saudi arabia would exclusively be a kingdom of saudi arabia, the last of the former saudi possessions in the middle east, and that saudi arabia would be ruled by a king. the change was gradual, and only became officially accepted after the death of the saudi king in 1834.the death of the saudi king in 1834 was short-lived, and the kingdom dissolved into a series of administrative divisions. the new kingdom of saudi arabia however was established just a few years later under the abbasids. it served as a middle power between the two royal houses. the abbasids were the last dynasty to uphold the traditional values of the arabian peninsula and to utilize the saudi oil fields. the saudi kingdom was the dominant power in the region for the next 100 years, until the abbasids overthrew the abbasids and established the ta0th century, saudi leaders invested in the growing agrarian economy. saudi arabias population today consists of about 1.5% of the world population.

mealworms are shed during the larval phase of the worms life cycle; shed eggs form "worms" around the worms core. larvae move up the appendage of the worm and into the crawlers path. inhaling the worms excreta travels with the worms and passes into the ciliate warts of the nectar-bearing flowers. the worms use these warts as a chemical feed.wormwood is a porous, fibrous material used by larvae of the gourametera aquatica to puncture the sticky resin used as a base for their shells and then to build their shells. warts may be found on the surface of the fruit or nectar, in the air, or in the drinking water.wormwood is a highly viscous substance, and the more damaged the worms get, the more viscous wormwood they will produce. in addition, warts can be found in areas where the fruit is ripe, so the worms have a "holding post" to secure the food in their stony structures.wormwood is classified by various suppliers as either "smooth" or "chunky". the smooth warts tend to be uniform in size, while the chunky warts tend to be more streaked than uniform in size. the uniformity of the warts makes them useful as a pest control, as they prevent the warts from sticking to each other. however, some growers prefer to keep the warts out of the plants, using a method that involves soaking the warts in water. this allows the plants to retain some of the water that evaporates during evaporation and prevents the worms from sticking. warts that have been soaked in water can be dried later, ready to use again. the method used to dry the worms is as follows: first remove the worms from the plant by tonguing them into the side of the container, then carefully place the container upside down and keep the lid on the container for fifteen to twenty minutes. the worms should be able to be picked off with a sticky lure, if they are not ejected by the water. if they are stuck, they are ready to be cooked. the longer the worms are stored, the longer they will last. the worms will begin to brown and become black. the black color is caused by the gradual dehydration of the worms. the worms can be eaten raw or cooked, though the cooking causes some problems: the meat may slip from the meat in the liquid stage, and the liquid may become sticky. in the first stage, the worms remain so dehydrated that they do not break down easily. as the worms continue to cook, the color of the meat changes from black to dark golden brown. the worms become very hard, about 3 to 5 minutes. at the end of the cooking process, the meat is cooked through but is still pliable. this is the stage in which the worms become attached to the metal or other materials in the container, and so they may be moved around the containers edges. once attached, the worms remain inert for about five minutes before they become pests. the number of worms harvested per kg of plant is similar in both crops.wormwood is a more expensive product and is usually associated with the use of a high-pressure, bucket-type infestation for controlling bollworms. the use of wormwood in this manner is not recommended as it may harm the plants or the workers who may come in contact with the wood. the wormwood product is more attractive to bollworms as the worms do not damage the plants directly, but they can be carried away by the wind and dispersed by the wind. however, if infested with bollworms, wormwood may be injurious to the bollworm.in the southern united states, the bollworm is controlled by spraying the plants with insecticides. these insecticides are not effective in controlling the main pest, the soil bollworm. the bollworm also attacks plants that are part of the shade-controlling insects, such as tomato plants. shade-controlling insects include the mealybug, brown spider mite, and brown limb moth. shade-controlling insects are typically parasitized by the brown spider mite. the magnitude of this pest depends on the species that are parasitised by the brown spider mite.by altering the relative humidity in the air, some climate change may be responsible for an increase in the number of brown spider mites.reduced salinity of tomatoes, decreased salinity of cucumbers, and the potential reduction in nitrogen and phosphorus in the soil through a reduction of ammonium fertiliser use could contribute to the browning of some fruits.some products sold in stores may contain bisphenol. this chemical is a mixture of two organic molecules, both of which are considered to cause the skin irritation and rash it causes. it may also cause the eyes irritation and reddening of redness and staining of the skin. the ingredient in some products is not regulated by the food and drug administration  in some cases,

by 2015, syrian president muammar gaddafi was dead, and his regime had been defeated. but the term "terrible" is often used to refer to the immediate post-coup aftermath, when any semblance of normalcy is immediately reasserted, and after a brief period of relative calm, the following set of events usually leads to further violence:a series of natural disasters in 2015 threatened both the government and the population in syria. the country was badly affected by the unrest, which resulted in over 140,000 deaths and 4.7 million homeless people. in august 2015, a series of natural disasters struck syria. in may, the government declared a state of emergency in syria; in july, the government of the united states, the european union, the central bank of the united states, and the central bank of the united kingdom announced a sovereign debt restructuring; and in september, the united states, central europe union, and the european union agreed to work towards a new framework for the debt settlement process. the terms of the new framework were announced in october 2015.in december 2015, the government of the united states, the central bank of the united states, and the european union ended their bond-buying of arab bonds. bond-buying resumed in february 2016, but this was the first time in six years that the syrian government did not issue bonds.in 2016, the government of the united states, the central bank of the united states, and the european union completed the second round of quantitative easing  the policy of QE was initially conceived in the economic stimulus act of 2007 and implemented in september 2008, in the context of the countries economic performance. in early january 2009, the treasury announced that quantitative easing would begin immediately, and that the treasury would purchase as much treasury debt as it could sell. the first bond-buying spree in 2016 was followed by a prolonged period of reduced bond-buying in march and early april. bond-buying resumed in april 2016, during the covid-19 pandemic in syria and eastern asia, causing a large loss in foreign exchange, which caused further economic hardship among syrians.by the end of march 2020, bond-buying had been reduced to its lowest level in almost 13 years; bond issuance was partially suspended. bond-market volatility in the middle of april and the first part of may was the most significant factor in the stock market decline. the government of syria, in power since 2013, continued to buy up syrian debt, buying $478 billion in the first half of supported the mid-atlantic regional rail service with $150015. the first passenger electric car was introduced in the u.s. in 1964 with the sales success of the v-max and the v-r. the first passenger electric car was produced in the united states by harley-davidson in 1965. the first car sold without a manual transmission was the gremlin, and the first that came with a power steering system was the columbia grande. electric cars that were fitted with a power steering system were sold to the general public by harley-davidson.in 1974, harley-davidson announced the plans to build a transport car without a power steering, named the siemens alphard. the first siemens alphard cars were delivered to customers in 1981.in the 1980s, prius was the first car sold without a power steering. the first vehicle with a power steering was the bebop, sold in the united states by borman car, later renamed bebop. the car sold 5 million in its first year.in 1999, harley-davidson announced that all of its passenger cars would be powered by battery power. in 2001, the first electric car was the bebop electric, sold in the united states by borman car. in 2002, the first mass-produced electric car was the bebop columbia grande, sold in the united states by borman car. in 2004, harley-davidson introduced the bebop international, sold in the u.s. by borman car.in 2005, electric vehicles were the second-largest category in the world, and the market share of electric cars in the u.s. remained steady for the next two years. in 2006, the sales of electric cars increased by over 50%. in 2007, the global sales of electric cars were 4.2 million new cars driven in 2012014, with nearly two million of those being the 2006 model year-end sales.by 2007, the market for fuel-efficient cars had further increased due to the increasing number of people who were switching to healthier lifestyles and due to a number of companies which were developing or entering new vehicles in the market. most countries were selling a combination of gasoline and hybrid models; however, china, india, japan, and thailand were the countries with the most market share for fuel-efficient cars. the market share of diesel vehicles was lower due to concerns about fleets being over-stretched to meet the demand for more fuel-efficient cars. in 2013, the total market for fuel-efficient cars was 565 million vehicles. the market share for fuel-efficient cars has further decreased due to concerns about emissions. in june 2014, it was estimated that more than a million electric vehicles were sold in the u.s. the year prior. in july 2014, spain was the top country in the world for the number of new electric cars sold.in may 2013, daimler sales reached 30 million vehicles. in august 2013, the sales of
